title: A slow burn which leads to a final fury
review: Spoiler alert What I loved about his movie was that it was a mystery that didn't even really let on that it was a mystery.  Because the "secret" was let out by the first round of viewers and/or critics, most knew that it was a mystery going in but, as far as we know throughout the movie, Soze is a man or a myth, etc.  We don't know because the movie's depression hooks us.  The idea of Soze is a black hole that slowly collapses along the way and the movie's intensity and riveted focus on characters keeps the "truth" in the distance until it pounces on us in the final sequences.  Until then, it is a well shot and often boring crime drama about a group of career losers who function well enough to be successful deviants.  The movie deserves it's rating because of the fascinating character development throughout and the lightening quick puzzle fitting at the end.  The character's other then Keaton are not very deep (no Verbal is not very deep) but that is a plus here.  They are sympathetic criminals but the script keeps them as just that, criminals.  In other words, it doesn't insult the audiences intelligence, even though it does portray the criminals in a positive light throughout.  The technical aspect is also quite excellent.  Little things, such as the light bulb dangling on the boat, accompanied by a light, jingling musical score, are spellbinding.  Such moments also lighten the movie's comatose mood.  The movie's soundtrack is as dour and boring as it gets but it wears on me after awhile and helps me get into the movie's mood, aka a black hole.  This is depressing stuff and the director doesn't try to find a silver lining in any of it.  Stephen Baldwin is the movie's Doc Holliday, a flowery, yet one dimensional, nut case.  Benicio Del Toro supplies comic relief and provides his characters "tight a**" distinction with nice subtlety to the point that you almost don't notice it.  Kevin Pollack has the movie's coolest role, playing a character that just doesn't give a you know what and he gets to explode throughout.  Spacey is such a naturally aloof actor that his roles come off as mysterious even when they are not supposed to be.  Gabriel Byrne has a tricky dual role.  We always sense him as being reformed, but Agent Kujan never describes him as anything less then pure evil.  This duality, which is never really explored, helps fuel the mystery.  The action is slick, moody and depressed, setting up the audience for the final revelation.  About the only real words for this movie after I've seen it are, "Whoa" and "Wow."  "Whoa" describes the movie's slow burn that never really flames out and "Wow" is the admiration for the great ending which ties it all together and lets the audience off of the hook. Probably the most subtle great movie I have ever seen.  If you are looking for grandeur, don't watch this movie.

title: Kevin Spacey rules
review: A "simple" movie and it ruled! Kevin Spacey and rest of the cast pulled out a great movie. Plot was very clever and the ending was worth to wait. You just have to watch it, it never gets boring and the suspense is kept into the very ending.

title: No matter how many times you watch this masterpiece, it never ceases to amaze you
review:
"The Usual Suspects" is the greatest crime thriller ever made, no contest whatsoever. The plot focuses on a cop (Chazz Palminteri), who interrogates the only survivor of a massacre on a boat, gimp Roger "Verbal" Kint (Kevin Spacey). Kint tells him of a police line-up that happened two weeks earlier, and the story starts.

Members of the line-up are crime veteren Keaton (Gabriel Byrne), slightly psychotic McManus (Stephen Baldwin), clever Hockney (Kevin Pollak) and smoothie Fenster (Benicio Del Toro). Each actor plays their part so well that you don't even recognize them. Byrne looks more lazy than usual. Baldwin looks thin, and you forget that he's even a Baldwin brother.

Of course, none of these performances match Spacey's. He walks, talks and acts nothing like any of his previous characters. Spacey isn't just a fifteen minute star, he's a classic actor.

And this is a classic movie, 9/10.

title: OH' THAT CHEATED FEELING!!!
review:
I expected the end,I was so sure after the line up that I had it all figured out. Keyser Soze couldn't fool me then the twists and turns came and I wasn't so sure and at the end , I guess I was plain mad. But he was brilliant though I hated him but give him credit, Keyser Soze was brilliant.

The Usual Suspects is a good movie simply because of an excellent cast. Each crook is a mastermind in his own right. This isn't one of my favourites though, much overhyped methinks.

Kudos to Bryan Singer.

title: If you´re a lover of great endings... then you have to see this one!
review:
If you talk about great films, you surely have to include this one, as one of the most original and intelligent endings ever made. But of course this movie doesn´t resume only to the ending.

Five men. Five criminals. One man. Keyser Soze. Who is he? No one knows. After being arrested by the police, these five man decide to cooperate with each other to gain some money. From here on, strange things will star to happen, as one man decide to hire them.

We can compare it to "Snatch", but if we're talking about twisted endings, "Jacob´s Ladder" and "Primal Fear" can match up this masterpiece.

Great Film. Great Direction. Great Acting. Great Ending. With these four ingredients you make a movie that goes down in history. Singer plays with the spectator's mind until the very ending, when all is explained and concluded. Great performances, especially by Spacey.

8 out of 10

title: One ofthe most intelligent crime-thrillers ever!
review:
One of the my personal best as far as absolute favorites. The events leading up to a fateful night at a Los Angeles harbor are traced from the viewpoint of a crippled con artist from Queens. You never know how much of what is said is genuine, since the narrator is of limited intelligence and naive in comparisson to his former partners.

After securing immunity by the D.A., "Verbal" Kint is coerced into telling a New York-based Customs agent David Kujan about what happened between the line-up six weeks earlier, where he met his compatriots, and the night that a boat allegedly carrying narcotics was destroyed. Kujan has played somewhat of a Javert to one of Verbal's associates, Dean Keaton, an ex-cop from New York who was trying to go straight after a career as a hijacker, and settle down with his lovely attorney girlfriend--or so Verbal paints him to be. The other three, McManus, Fenster, and Todd Hockney, create an array of decidedly different people. Keaton, always the reluctant partisipant, spars often with McManus, a psychotic given to fits of violent rage, vying for the role of leader of the gang. Fenster, McManus' partner from before, is a mild-mannered Latino who tries to stay out of the way of things. Hockney is a mechanic and explosives expert who doesn't care about anyone but himself, but tensions flare between him and McManus as well. Verbal is sort of the odd man out: crippled so that he is limited in physicality, and inexperienced in the art of hijacking.

After pulling off a successful job in New York, the five men travel to LA to meet McManus and Fenster's fence, Redfoot. After a job goes bad they are conronted with a mysterious attorney working for a legendary gangster named Keyser Soze. The attorney, Kobayashi, charges them with one final job.

The story, as presented by Verbal Kint, presents one final question: Who is Keyser Soze. Keaton doesn't believe in him. Kujan believes Keaton IS him. And it ends with a twist that you may never see coming (unless you read between the lines of the reviews posted).

Gabriel Byrne plays the reluctant Irish cop with conviction. Kevin Spacey's Oscar-winning (and star-making) Verbal Kint seems the most mild and simple of people. Chazz Palminteri's David Kujan is perfect to counter the image Verbal describes of Keaton. Smaller supporting roles by Pete Postlethwaite, as Kobayashi, Dan Hedaya, as a restless LA cop, Giancarlo Esposito as an FBI agent friend of Kujan's, and Benicio Del Toro's sly Fenster (five years before he won the Oscar for "Traffic"), help to give fully-fleshed characters to Christopher McQuarrie's already-rich storytelling, and Bryan Singer's ("X-Men," "X2") career-making direction.

title: What more can be said?
review: I mean really, what more can be said?  This is totally #1 on my list and should be high on yours.  I love this movie because of the cheated feeling it gives you.  The best way to watch it is to know nothing about it... just sit and watch.  Don't think, just sit and watch.  Trust me, you will love it... unless you don't like being made a fool of.

title: Excellent Film
review:
Warning: Possible spoilers, but it would be hard to find a review of this film without any.

I just finished watching this film for the second time, and it was even more enjoyable and interesting. More enjoyable just because I got to reassess every scene with my knowledge of the incredible ending. More interesting because even under such scrutiny, the acting and cinematography fit perfectly with the mind-boggling conclusion. If the story is unbelievable in parts, then that is perfectly fitting. Part of this film's beauty lies in the false endings which multiple times lead a viewer to think he/she has outwitted the film and anticipated the ending. For me, at least, the realization of the truth (insofar as this movie permits any real truth to be found) was sudden and unexpected, only seconds before the film revealed it to me. Great analysis of the gullibility of viewers and the willingness of an audience to accept whatever is shown to them. 9/10

title: Top heist thriller
review:
This is a deservedly acclaimed thriller movie that is brilliantly written and executed.

My biggest hint to those who haven't seen this movie is to pay close attention to the opening scene, and keep it in mind throughout the rest of the story; it is very important. And remember the way the story is unfolding.



For those who have seen the story, I have to say my fav scene is the penultimate one where the central character thinks he's got caught, and is getting ready to plea bargain. That and the scene where Chazz Palminteri's character first bursts in and demands Kevin Spacey's character tell him about Kaiser Souze are the two most effective and secretly revealing scenes in the story. They're the ones that work effectively no matter what your reading of the film is.

title: An Ensemble Masterpiece...
review: Besides the excellent acting from all involved, and besides the unpredictable emotion-tugging twist, and besides the witty dialogue, and also besides the subtle humor, there is an incredible story.  One of my top three favorite movies ever.

title: Amazing Movie
review: Cristopher Mcquarrie did a terrific job on this screen write.  Bryan Singer is an awesome director, and all of the actors and actresses did a tremendous job on this movie.  This may be one of the greatest movies of all time.

title: My Favorite Movie of All-Time
review: I'm not gonna pretend to be some sort of a film critic here because I'm not one and your average moviegoer isn't either. All I can say is this: "The Usual Suspects" is the most enjoyable movie from start-to- incredible-finish that I have ever seen, and for that it easily gets a 10 out of 10 in my book. And for those of you who judge the whole movie based on the twist ending, I knew who Keyser Soze was before I ever saw the movie because of Kevin Spacey's Academy Award acceptance speech when he said, "Whoever Keyser Soze is, he's getting stinkin' drunk tonight!" Even if you know it in advance, you can still appreciate the brilliance of it, and for that it gets my highest recommendation.

title: Only 17th in the top 250???
review:
In my opinion this is one of the greatest films ever. It's been my number one for a good few years now. It is sheer brilliance from start to finish (especially the finish)

I know many people say they predicted the ending, but come on, they can't have predicted the whole of the ending, and because of that, this still remains the best twist in a movie to date, and I even mean better than Memento.

I don't want to give anything away for people who haven't seen it, but to those people I will ask ... Why haven't you seen it? Go, find it now. No, stop reading this and go and find a copy of the movie. I said stop reading!!

Let's just hope Bryan Singer and Christopher McQuarrie team up again for another movie and see if they can do it again.

title: Great movie, great twist
review:
May contain SPOILERS.

I've only just seen this film and I was blown away by its ending. The story revolves around the questioning of 'Verbal' Kint, (Kevin Spacey), who is interrogated by police in California to help with a mysterious occurrence on board a boat in port, where a vicious bloodbath had taken place. The key is the identification of one Kaiser Sosay, (I don't know if I spelt it right), who is apparently the orchestrator of these events. I won't reveal the ending, though it is amazing, see for yourself.

The story is gripping, and there are fine performances by Stephen Baldwin, Gabriel Byrne, Benicio Del Toro among others. As ever Spacey shines with considerable charisma. Also good is Pete Postlethwaite, (albeit speaking in an unusual accent), though his screen time is limited.

Overall this is a stunning crime thriller, which fans of films such as "LA Confidential" would certainly enjoy. I promise you, you'll love the ending.

10/10

title: All time favourite
review: Simply the best film in its genre(s)! It is a tremendous script. It is perfectly casted. It has a plot that'll keep you spell bound to the screen. I cannot understand why this film isn't placed higher on the imdb.com top 250. The plot and the dramatic scenes creates an atmosphere that is difficult to describe to those who hasn't had the pleasure of experience this marvelous motion picture. See it now! Every actor does a great job, especially Kevin Spacey, Gabriel Byrne and Chazz Palminteri that really shows his qualities.

title: Brilliant
review: I really enjoyed this film. It was very cleverly crafted together, and anyone who appreciates a good movie should like this one. Kevin Spacey is a delight to behold as the pitiful narrator of this clever story involving five men who plot revenge on the police force. The twist in the tale is excellent, and long after the film has ended, you're still trying to get your head around it. I would recommend this to anyone.

title: Praise for the surprise ending
review:
The Usual Suspects, whilst not only being a tremendous film in itself has definatly led the way to spawning a total shuffle in the way that films in the Crime genre are made.

The tremendous script and birth on our screens of Kevin Spacey and Benicio Del Toro made this film a landmark, not only because it launched the careers of both of those actors, but also because the shock ending, which is not at all typical of crime films has spawned many films, not only crime films which base the entire narrative structure on the surprise ending. When you watch films like Fight Club or any film by M. Night Shyamalan, you can clearly see the influence held by The Usual Suspects on these films. Bryan Singers direction and Christopher McQuarrie's screen writing should both be praised and lavished by fans of any film which has a tale changing twist at the end of it.

This film is legendary and is totally responsible for the creation of as new movie genre in itself, the surprise ending!

title: This movie blew me away!
review: After watching Pulp Fiction, it became hard for me to find new films these days that excited me.  I mean pulp was so unique and orginal that I was so stunned when I first watched it.  I couldn't believe my eyes, it was funny, violent and it wasn't meaningless either because at the end of each story there is a message of redemption. Now it brings me to Usual Suspects. I didn't really know what to expect when I first watched it because it looked like it was going to be some prison movie.  Boy, was I wrong.  The plot just kept twisting and turning which kept me on the edge of my seat.  It was suspenseful and mysterious, the whole bit with Keyser Soze, it's gold! And the ending is what made this movie.  THe film truly has THE BEST ENDING in any movie ever made.  I'm not gonna ruin it for those who haven't seen it. So I desperately urge all of you who haven't seen it to go out to either rent it or buy it.  Buying it is good because this one is a keeper, I have a copy of it myself.  It's always fun to watch it with someone who haven't seen it just to see their reaction. And of course, great performances on behalf of Kevin Spacey (who's career skyrocketed after his role as Verbal Kint) and Benicio Del Toro (whose talent was recognized after his useless role as Fenster where he basically took a guy who only had like two lines in the whole movie and actually was able to turn him into a character that people care about after watching it.)

title: Much spoken, little said
review: Though hardly new to American Cinema, the unduly praising of works saturated with empty chatter but totally void of meaningful exposition has ballooned out of control since the 1990s. Few illustrate this better than Al Pacino and Tom Hanks, who won Oscars in that decade for their inane utterances while the substance-driven competition was overlooked. Next we see The Usual Suspects, a similarly touted piece that does little to hide its loquacity, and even includes a ranting narrator named Verbal Kint. Sure there are duplicated moments of Tarentino gunplay where bullets and blood fly around, but that's the limit of the movie's action. After all, just when you are about to see someone particularly irritating be blown away (i.e. Kobayashi or perhaps Verbal himself), McQuarrie pops out and yells "Just kidding!" Some have likened watching this film to being on a transatlantic plane ride and forced to sit next to a thirtysomething salesman who simply won't shut up. Luckily, movies on average are only two hours long, and exits may be used safely at all times.

Anyways... the script is well done (2nd award for this film), impressively covering all the characters. The ending didn't help the movie improve as did the last twenty minutes of Se7en. Although it is indeed a good ending its not shocking. Although this movie is good, its hardly great. 8.5/10

title: If you like films comfortably predictable this isn't for you
review:
But what the hell, you should still watch it!

For not only is this film beautifully shot, not only does it set the mood perfectly with a sumptuous original sound-track, not only does it...

It also has one of the greatest acting performances you'll ever see, the thing though is, it's so good that you'll miss it first time. Spacey's performance can only really be appreciated with repeat viewings. And he is just the stand out actor from an Oscar winning ensemble, including Benicio Del Toro, Pete Postlethwaite, Gabriel Byrne, Chaz Palminteri, all at their peak. The on-screen chemistry is highlighted in The Line-up Scene, where a piece of editing makes history (It was originally an out-take which was later decided worked better than the original)... you'll see.

This is a film that is so well written that in every scene you find yourself grinning and yearning to find something out (half of the time you don't know what you want to know, you just want to know more). And you get it. All the time there is the story about 'who is Keyser Soze?' a mythical(perhaps) crime-lord around which the exposition is set. But you find yourself forgetting this while you are taken on a thrill ride of car-jacking, jewel robbery and murder, only for it to re-emerge at the end and hit you in the face with a sledge hammer.

If you like to guess the endings of films and feel cheated if you can't even though you were outsmarted, then you should still watch this classic at least twice. If you like films in any other capacity you should enjoy infinite repeat viewings.

Xander

title: Add this flick to your collection...
review: Or at least go rent it!  This is one of the best movies of all-time. Great cast, dynamic plot, superb acting, immaculate direction, phenomenal dialogue...need I go on? title: Great Movie
review: This is one of the best movies that I had seen in a while. I thought that Kevin Spacey's preformance was excellent and that the story was great (especially the finish). I thought that the other actors, while they weren't as well known as Spacey did an excellent job as well. *****

title: The not so intriguing suspects
review:
Ah, yes, "The Usual Suspects". My expectations were high, as is was called a "masterpiece" and received a 8.7 rating on IMDB. But, er, unfortunately, it just didn't work for me.

The story line is not that intriguing.

The events are not that intriguing.

And most characters are even less intriguing.

All the alleged "complexity" (such as the shifts in time) is meant to make the story more interesting, but it cannot hide the blanket of shallowness that lies over this film.

The film is made in such a way that the viewer should care about the well-being and fate of a group of ruthless criminals. That's at least how I saw it. But I can't and didn't feel sorry for any of them, so it was hard to get attached to the events. But the "real" good guys, i.e., the cops, didn't manage to get hold of my attention either (they just talk, talk, talk about things I didn't really care about), so I didn't really emphasize with anyone, which makes viewing a lot less entertaining.

All in all, I find it quite hard to believe that this film made it to #16 in the IMDB list. Starting out with an initial "6" for being mediocre, I add 2 points for the surprise ending, although it's a "stand-alone" scene, which cannot save the rest of the film. Further, I subtract, in total, 1 point for (a) the extensive supposedly-tough-but-actually-quite-annoying-after-a-while use of the "f" word, and (b) the fact that this film features a "Baldwin".

Rating from the Dutch judge: 7 (out of 10).

title: Fine for the genre
review:
I guess my one-line summary is "damning with faint praise," as the saying goes.... But I really do want to praise this movie. It's one of the best films I'm seen in a while; smartly written, beautifully directed and shot. The acting is great. I have to say that, while not as stunning as, say, the ending to The 39 Steps, the surprise ending to Suspects is cool enough.

I am a little surprised at how high Suspects is on the IMDb top 250. But, in defense of those who would gladly see it ensconced there, I will add that "heroic crook"-type movies tend to put me off. It's very hard to humanize a crook in the movies as far as I'm concerned. I see that Suspects holds these guys at a sort of arms length by highlighting an ultimate dog-eat-dog lack of honor among thieves, at the highest level. So that salvages it a bit for me. But, for example, Suspects doesn't come near the humanization of criminality that The Godfather does. I saw that the movie Heat tried to cop some of that same prestige (by showing the crooks having happy family dinners, etc.), but for me failed achieve an integration. I'm telling you; you'll always have a hard time convincing me to let criminal elements on screen into the tabernacle of my heart! Godfather does this, and a look at how it succeeds could be instructive. Suspects only succeeds to the extent that it doesn't make a pretense of getting you under the skins of the malefactors in that typical time-honored cinematic manner.

I would recommend this movie as cinematic art. I cannot recommend it as a movie that succeeds on a visceral level. Which means I can only recommend it in a narrow sense. Sorry.

title: Absolutely amazing.
review:
*SPOILERS AHEAD*

I've been speaking to my friends recently about that Top 100 Films that was on the television recently. We got talking about this masterpiece. Some people overhearing us said that the ending didn't make sense because he was hiding when Keaton got shot. As I to explained to them, what you see on the boat at the end, is what Verbal is telling the police, what you see on the boat at the start is what really happened. And other people didn't think Keyser didn't exist at all (which in a way could be true).

So in the end, we forgot about the Top 100 and just talked about The Usual Suspects. One of my friends simply said it was crap, he was 'politely' asked to leave.

To say that this film is crap is to be quite naive, as is to say this film would be nothing without the final twist. The final twist simply adds to it, it doesn't make it. What makes the film are the fantastic performances, the great chunks of clever dialogue and the characters.

Kevin Spacey is one of my favourite actors and rightly deserved his Best Supporting Actor Oscar for this film. Verbal Kint is quite a hard character to get right, because you had to be vulnerable, but at the same time be well.....*MAJOR SPOILER, DO NOT READ IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN IT* Keyser Soze.

Anyway, I love this film, well worth getting, on DVD if you can, because there are some excellent extras including two commentaries.

9/10

title: FANTASTIC
review: No real words can express how good this movie is! everything about the movie is about as perfect as Hollwood perfection can be! The film did everything right, actors were brilliant, script is mind bendingly brilliant, the direction and everything was blissfuly perfect. I'd recomend this movie to anyone and everyone! can't say enough good so i shall say no more. check it out!

title: There are "invisible" people out there who control the way we live more than we would care to think.
review:
This is an immaculate movie experience without one low point.

The movie is brilliant in many ways: intricate twisting plot, action

packed, great character development, suspense, sinister mood,

black comedy, subtlety, realism and social comment. Well, there

you have a whole lot of skills to put in one movie, and all these

elements combine wonderfully to create a perfect whole by the

end, yet leaving you disturbed. The film will also entertain

teenagers, those seeking escapism, as well as intellectuals. The

casting goes a long way to making the film also. Spacey is simply

brilliant, superbly supported by the other main actors. The movie

teases and controls us. A major understated theme is that we are

being controlled to some degree by unseen, unknown people...in

a world of computer data and cross matching, we simply have no

idea about the extent to which we are known, monitored, even

controlled; a very scary and relevant issue.

title: No wonder it won the best screenplay
review: Since watching it I always use Keyser Soze as my nick name because the character looks so cool. Buy/rent/steal the dvd if you must because you will not regret it. I watched it on tv but then I realized that I have to buy the dvd as I know that the dvd will be part of my properties that is going to be inherited by my family.

title: One of the best thrillers I have ever seen
review: Great acting and great direction are the words that describes the movie The Usual Suspects. Kevin Spacey shows that he has a lot of acting skills and the direction by Bryan Singer is just outstanding. A very good movie to watch. A must watch.

title: KEYSER SOZE IS....
review:
Returned to this following a DVD Christmas present. What can you say? Looks excellent, excellent script, excellent cast and one of the top 5 endings ever. Easily one of the best 3 films of the 1990s. You'll remember when Spacey was good, Byrne was a star and Del Toro was a baby.

Will enjoy returning to this time after time.

title: Not your usual movie
review:
I have heard nothing but good about this movie. Someone actually closed his eyes and shook his head in pity when he found out I hadn't yet seen it. I now know why.

This movie is a modern classic. It is one of the most popular movies ever made, one of the greatest movies ever made, and quite possibly the most spoofed movie in Hollywood (spoofed in both Wrongfully Accused AND Scary Movie).

Kevin Spacey did very well. There's really no other way to describe Spacey's performance.

Anyway, I gave this movie a 10/10. This was one hell of a movie.

title: SPOILERS: about the ending
review:
Another user wrote: "The 'twist' ending was the equivalent of

finding out that everything up until that point had been a dream."

Others wrote similar things. I don't agree. Keep in mind that Kint

testified before a grand jury, so anything that they could check had

to be true (e.g. the attack on the taxi cops, and Edie working on the

extradition case.) He couldn't lie too much and still have a

consistent story. So I believe that his story is supposed to be at

least 90% true. Kujan figured out that Kint was lying because he

saw the names that Kint read off the wall. Most of these, Kint just

used in anecdotes to build up his character. The only one that he

worked into the story was "Kobayashi." So that's one thing we can

be sure he lied about: the man who picks him up at the end is not

really named Kobayashi. We should know that anyway, because

he doesn't look Japanese at all. That's one of the few clues that

there's something wrong with Kint's story.

title: This ones a cracker!
review:
I saw this movie on video and I think its an excellent, gripping thriller that plays tricks with its audience, leading it down one blind alley after another, dealing in deliberate confusion and double-cross. Its refusal to come clean until its final revelation may infuriate some people, but I think thats part of it's appeal, its aided by some nicely edgy performances from its cast.

The plot is simple enough five crooks, who meet in a police line-up and decide to work together on a couple of robberies, come to believe that they are being manipulated by a mysterious master criminal.

The good thing about The Usual Suspects is not method acting or directorial flair, but its vivid, audacious, relentless intelligence. This really is a modern classic.

Mark: 8.5/10

title: The Usual Man
review: This is a must see movie, not just because of the ending but because it also has a strong cast and everyone seems to know their role very well.  The movie unfolds in a manner that can be well followed and i bet almost anyone will appreciate its creativity.

title: Great Action Movie
review:
The Usual Suspects, directed by Bryan Singer, is a great action movie and deserves a rental. The story is very thought out and you will be surprised at the end of it. Use great attention while watching it, though, you might need to watch it a couple times to get the most of it, or watch it with the commentary on the DVD.

The acting is great. Kevin Spacey, which is one of my faves, does a great job as Verbal Kint, and Benicio Del Toro plays an excellent, and funny, Fred Fenster.

The sound is okay. Nothing really to special. Music in the tense spots, etc.

I wouldnt call this one of my favorites, but I would definitely watch it again. Pick this one up if you have never seen it before, its worth it.

4.5/5

title: Incredible!
review: This movie is quite possibly one of the best movies that I have come across. It has a wonderfully developed story from beginning to end, and is wonderfully cast. Each of the characters are well developed and incredibly unique.  This is a must see for anyone who is a fan of any sort of thriller type movie.  It is a movie you have to think through, it's a movie loaded with action, and it even has its moments of comedic relief.  It is a must see.

title: Watch this.
review: This film is among the most innovative films made, and my favourite film full stop. It's incredible in the age of $200million movies that this $5million picture should have such impact, but it's tight storyline and a fantastic turn from Kevin Spacey particularly as well as great displays from the rest of the cast put it at number one in my list - and i've seen a lot of films. Unmissable.

title: One of the best of its GENRE!!
review: Simply the best!I'm spell bound,seeing this film for the first time was a good experience but when I saw it for the second time I realized that it was more than a suspense thriller.Every one of the actors was perfect in his role,especially Kevin spacey and Gabriel Byrne.The ending was terrific not that the ending was good but the way in which it ended was superb to watch.A must see film.Kevin Spacey has proved over the years that he is a really talented actor.

title: The Acting Is Superb, Like The Movie!
review:
Well, what can I say. This is one of the best movies to ever grace the silver screen. The plot is very well crafted, the ending is first class and the acting is very well done.

Kevin Spacey is a master at what he does. His characters in American Beauty and especially The Usual Suspects are spellbinding. His best performance in this movie was the way he tricked everybody into believing his story. Gabriel Byrne has many great movies. Movies like Stigmata and End Of Days were good but it's in The Usual Suspects that he shows his true colours. His best part was when he is talking to the D.A (hehe). The other ones such as Benicio Del Toro, Stephen Baldwin, Kevin Pollak, Chazz Palminteri and Pete Postlethwaite are masters too but not like the first two.

All in all, a great movie.

10 out of 10

title: One of the most intense movies ever
review: A wonderfully confusing and powerful movie. This movie is all about acting. It is full of wonderful actors and scenes built just for them. Everytime I watch this movie I fall more in love with it.

title: Definatley in the top 5 movies of all time on my list.
review: This movie is nearly unparallel. The Godfather is undoubtedly the greatest movie but untill this movie i didnt think that anything other than Pulp Fiction compared. the plot was well written and the actors were perfectly cast. the dialogue was briliantly put together to keep you entertained and at the same time give you all the clues to figuring out the mystery. this movie will be in my top five fur shur.

title: The devil inside
review:
This is as good as it gets as a mystery movie, as a villain movie, as a guess who did it movie, as every movie ever made....

The Usual Suspects just excels on every level with outstanding acting (Byrne, Postlewaith, the great Spacey etc.), the storyline, the directing etc. it´s already a classic.

The devil is inside and he´s still out there and his name is Kaysar Sose!

You just have to admire this masterpiece. Macaulay J. Connor 10/10

title: watch it again, and again, and again
review: The first time I saw this movie I was floored.  I had to rewind it and watch it again.  I probably saw it 5 times before I took it back to the video store. The characters are great, the plot is edge of your seat and the writing and directing cannot be praised enough. If I have one complaint, it is because I like Benicio Del Toro so much, and he wasn't in it nearly as much as he should have been.  His character hadn't developed enough so that I could understand what he was saying the first time through.   So it was all the better for the movie, I guess,  but this is among my all time favorite movies.  It is a movie that I agreed with the critics about and the other fans.

title: Why Ebert gave this movie thumbs down, I shall never know!
review: Undoubtedly, amongst the best crime/gangster movies to grace the silver screen, this one will remain one of the top ten... Why? Because not only is "The Usual Suspects" a stylish crime movie, it's also a thriller packed with great twists and turns... and once you arrive to the climax... whoo, boy! Are you gonna be amazed. Don't be surprised if you find yourself gawking at the screen, because that's how I was when I got to the climax on my first viewing. Heck, everybody was! The whole movie is great, from the scenery to the dialogue to the music. Everything works in this movie, and the funny thing is that it works too perfectly. It may be too clever for its own good, but what the hey? We need more films like that. A clever script, a perfect cast, and a brilliant director all blend into one surprising movie. How can it ever fail? Even a movie where Stephen Baldwin lends a great performance has to be perfect, right? An all out excellent movie. Highly recommended masterpiece. Roger Ebert had to be in his worst mood before seeing this excellent movie to give it two thumbs down. It's a mystery that will never be solved. Even if you're not entirely convinced by the thousand positive reviews in this site... Give it a go, you won't be disappointed!

title: This is indeed a must see movie
review:
Brian Singer provides us with a magnificent crew of actors to tell this story. A story of mystique. A story about 5 criminals lined up in New York. A story about Keyser Soze. And a story you will not forget in weeks.

It's a difficult movie to write good comments about, but it's not difficult to admit I really enjoy myself every time I see it.

You will not forget your meeting with Keaton, McManus, Kint, Fenster, Huckson and of course Keyser Soze.

Haven't seen it yet? You'd better take your time soon, cause you'll want to watch it again and again.

title: a masterpiece of cinematic intrigue and suspense
review:
The Usual Suspects is, quite simply, a masterpiece of cinematic intrigue and suspense. At various points throughout its runtime, it is almost disarmingly comic, action-packed and insightful, yet at any given point when the film seems to be conforming to the cliches of its genre, the director is merely toying with the viewer and laying the foundations for one of cinema's most memorable climaxes.

The plot largely involves a police interrogation of Verbal Kint (Kevin Spacey) as to the events between the meeting of him and four other prolific criminals at a line-up and an arson attack on a suspected drug boat six weeks later. There is a series of flashbacks detailing how the band became implicated in the labyrinthine affairs of the fearsome criminal mastermind, Keyser Soze. This character is particularly fascinating, in spite of - or perhaps because of - the fact that he scarcely appears in the film.

The Usual Suspects benefits enormously from a lively (and Oscar-winning) script, especially during dialogue amongst the criminals themselves, but also because of the idiosyncracies of Verbal, who suffers from cerebral palsy. There are also several memorable acting performances, notably from Benicio del Toro, who steals every scene he speaks in with his bizarre and invariably profane accent.

Perhaps there are many weaknesses to this film, but the fact is that the strength of the conclusion is such that the viewer would be hard-pressed to recall them. The sheer originality of Bryan Singer's artistry overshadows any such flaws [Irish-American is one thing, but Gabriel Byrne's accent is surely closer to Bray than Boston]. The director preys on the assumptions and prejudices of the audience to draw it in, and as the final piece of the puzzle is about to be placed, the folly of these assumptions is exposed in spectacular fashion.

I feel anything further would be a spoiler so I'll conclude. Watch this movie, fall for its charms, take the bait and be utterly bowled over by what transpires. . .

title: One of the best movies!
review: The Usual Suspects is a brilliant film with an excellent screenplay and superb acting and directing.This movie is an all out entertainer.If you have'nt seen this movie shame on you.Go buy this because this movie deserves to be owned.

title: The Truth Known Till The End,Truly A Masterpiece!
review: This movie is truly a landmark of the modern detective movies.I Think the whole storyline is perfect! I can hardly find the doubtful points of the movie,and Kevin Spacy's performance is irresistible.This movie is a really must-see!

review:
I'll make this short and sweet. This movie is the best modern crime drama out there! It turned me on to watch anything that Kevin Spacey comes out with. And his performance in this is his best I've seen of his. Hence, his Oscar for Best Supporting Actor.

If you haven't seen this movie. Watch it!! You won't be disappointed.

title: Great movie if you didn't see the ending coming
review:
Alright so I enjoyed the movie, but I can't figure out where is the "masterpiece"... I mean a lot of people seem to have enjoyed the movie because of the ending, but come on guys, I knew who was the guy behind this 1h before the end...

The fact that all along I thought it was him (I wont say names since some of you might have not watched it) and figuring out in the end that he was indeed that person kinda frustrated me... I was happy to get the detailed explanation on how he did it at the end but beside that I felt pretty angry when I was done watching it. review: i thought this was a good movie with good acting and a great story, but to me, it wasn't all that involving. i don't know, i just saw it, maybe i will like it more the more i think about it. right now, maybe a 8.7 out of 10, which for me, is average.

title: Excellent
review:
I don't understand how anybody could not find something to like in this movie. It has a great cast from Kevin Spacey (who deservedly won an oscar) to Benicio Del Toro. The script, to say the least, is brilliant. Even if you don't particularly empathise with the characters, you can't help but be sucked into the suspense of the story. The direction, camerawork and music all capture the scene with precision. And the final twist at the end leaves you in shock, and the ending is, surprisingly, one of the most satisfying I have ever seen.

Quite simply, this is one of the best movies ever made and is worth the time of anyone who sees it.

title: Exuberantly ExQUISITE!
review: Surely a treat to watch Kevin Spacey once again with his voice and playful antics that he'd display on his face. Gabriel Byrne did good..and so did the other freaks. However , the credit goes to the Writer of the story..who made an effort thinking over the plot and remove the glitches in it.

title: Wonderful turn of events
review: I like everything in this movie, especially the work of Kevin Spacey. This film is a very good mix of young enthusiasm and elder experience.

title: absolutely fabulous
review: What more can i say. its great. I've watched it time and time again. I love Gabriel Byrne and Kevin Spacey. very good actors. I love the suspense and never bore of it. Tres magnific (if I've spelt that right). I always recommend it to people to watch. so go watch it now. Byeeeeee.

title: Great Mystery Movie, but No Classic
review:
I definitely enjoyed this movie. The performances by all of the lead actors were excellent. The characters were also very interesting, both as individuals and collectively.

***Possible SPOILERS***

The story was good also, but for me it had one fatal flaw. Why would Soze go through all the effort to eliminate the one man that could identify him, only to allow himself to be arrested? Sure no one knew it was him at the time of the arrest, but why risk the chance of anyone figuring it out?

It would have made alot more sense if he had just disappeared after killing Keaton. Now alot more people can identify him. I know he mentioned "never surfacing again", but if that was the case, then why bother killing the one guy in the first place.

So I enjoyed it for the mystery, but this flaw kept me from rating it a classic.

title: A Good Crime Thriller
review:
As others have mentioned - finding a modern movie with a descent plotline is a hard thing to do - but 'The Usual Suspects' shows that they do still occasionally occur.

Although this movie is good, I wouldn't call it as a masterpiece as it lacks the sophistication of classics of this genre such as 'Chinatown' etc... but is definitely still worth watching.

In the style of 'LA Confidential'.

If you're not a Kevin Spacey fan you soon will be after this.

title: McQuarrie changes the usual formula from 'who done it?' to 'who is it?'. Who is Keyser Soze?
review:
Bryan Singer's 'The Usual Suspects' is a masterpiece. From the ad hocery of the line up scene that lets the great cast shine, to the highly organized reminiscential scenes that help the audience understand McQuarrie's great script.

McQuarrie has written an amazingly intricate story filled with tension. It changes the usual formula of 'who done it?' to 'who is it?' creating a unique crime story.

Spacey is brilliant as disabled con man Verbal Kint. Byrne is great as con man gone straight Dean Keaton. Pete Postlethwaite is also amazing as the mysterious lawyer Kobayashi. Not to mention the performance of Palminteri as the frustrated Agent Dave Kujan. The Cast is full of class.

McQuarrie's dialogue is superb. Which is delivered with awesome credence. Especially from Spacey's character Verbal Kint who largely verbalizes the story to Agent Kujan and of coarse the audience.

Singer exposes the clues to this mystery in the most subtle fashion. This leads to one of the most surprising endings in the history of cinema. Who is Keyser Soze?

title: Modern Crime drama
review: Excellent movie, good acting, and a well told story.  Kevin Spacey won for best supporting actor and deserved it.  Well done crime drama with some twists and turns.  Eventhough you kind of figure it out 2/3rds of the way through it is quite fun watching the drama unfold.  This is one to watch again.

title: The best suspense thriller of the last 10 years.
review:
What the cops never figured out, and what I know now, was that these men would never break, never lie down, never bend over for anybody. Anybody.

Watch this movie once and the story and the acting will impress you. Watch it a 2nd and 3rd and you will be blown away. I have never seen a movie so well conceived so that watching again and again enhances the story. IF YOU HAVE NOT SEEN THIS MOVIE DO NOT FIND OUT ANYTHING ABOUT IT IN ADVANCE!!! Don't let others ruin the experience.

The greatest trick the devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't exist.

title: We need more films like this!
review: Shame Hollywood isn't capable of making more intelligent films like this  - instead product placement snd lowest common denominator is the name of the game. Film noir with interesting plot and good acting. I guess Spacey as the lead tells you that perhaps not is all as it seems. He seems to often turn up as a bit of a psycho!

title: Actors, script, director all present and correct. Excellent.
review:
Bryan Singer is one of a new wave of supremely talented Hollywood directors. The first film that he made a major splash with was 1995's The Usual Suspects. Taking it's title from a quote from the classic movie Casablanca, The Usual Suspects was pigeon-holed on it's release as a Tarantino-esque crime movie. Unfairly as it turns out for while Singer shares Tarantino's morally ambivalent attitude towards crime and criminals there are significant differences between the two directorial styles.

Singer's work with his actors is excellent, drawing top-notch performances from an unlikely cast. Before the film was released Spacey was merely a supporting man, Stephen Baldwin was considered one of the lesser talents from his family, Del Toro was an unknown and Kevin Pollak was thought of as a comic actor first and foremost.

As well as having a superb cast and being really well directed on a small budget, the script is superb, giving the actors more scope to do their excellent work. When Spacey took the Oscar for best supporting actor, and Christopher McQuarrie won for Best Original Screenplay it felt like a vindication for crime movie addicts everywhere. To talk too much of the plot is to murder the film, it really needs to be seen as a fresh experience, with high expectations and a blank mind.

title: My comments.
review: I have never seen a film as close to perfection as The Usual Suspects. It is the epitome of class, from the cast, to the soundtrack, to the locations, to the script. The way the characters develop and the mysteries of the enigmatic Keyser Soze adds to the complex, but fascinating story. Excellent.

title: Sheer brilliance!!!
review:
SPOILER The great thing that I realised about this movie wasn't the twist that fooled every person who ever watched it, but the fact that you can't help but fall for it.

Bryan Singer knows what he is doing to the audience and doesn't give you the chance to try make sense of what is going on. The film itself though is complicated and it is this that adds to the mystery of understanding it. Also the fact that you watch this time and time again and think that you understand it when really you can't get over the fact that you've been had.

Kevin Spacey gives a brilliant (Oscar winning) performance as the handicapped Verbal Kint, and you are shocked by the end when you come to the realisation that he is the infamous Kaiser Sosei, a name that has intrigued you throughout the film. Though if it weren't for the brilliant script and great direction the trick which has been played on the audience may not have worked at all. On the basis of this alone I would give nothing but praise for the film.

There has been no film of postmodern times that has pulled of a twist so good until this film came along. The only other film I would reccomend that does this just as well would have to be The Sixth Sense.

title: Confusing but brilliant
review:
Although I may seem sexist when I say this ( and I probably am being sexist) but women do not usually 'get' movies like this. I sat and watched the first 10 minutes with my Mum and we were so confused, we had to switch it off. An hour later I was bored again, so I thought I would give it another go and I am so glad I did.

I am not going to give away any of the plot, what I will say though is that the twist at the end is completely out of the blue unlike other predictable twists such as in The Sixth Sense. Again, the acting from Mr Spacey NEVER fails to impress me greatly and I am so pleased he won the oscar for his role as 'Verbal' because he totally deserved it.

If you absolutely hate films that skip backwards and forwards in time structure, have lots of characters and guns, then you probably won't like The Usual Suspects. However, if you're willing to give anything a go then WATCH IT - it would be a CRIME to miss it!!! (Sorry, terrible attempt at a joke)

title: Very good and worth seeing but...
review: I wouldn't call it a "brilliant masterpiece".  It IS a gripping thriller with great direction, convincing plot twists, and very strong performances BUT The ending is predictable.  Ten minutes before the movie was over I figured out what was going to happen and felt very let down.  But it is still worth recommending and renting for some summer suspense.  Just don't expect too much.

title: Usual suspected review
review:
Bryan singer directs Christopher McQuarrie's unique story following 5 criminals, one dope deal, one ambitious cops search for the truth and an anonymous crime lord. The Usual Suspects gave the 1990's back those masterpieces that had those amazing ironic climaxes like in "The Third Man" and gave a new meaning to those movies that most people may consider "weird', when in fact they just didn't understand a thing. The Usual suspects is not your usual film, and will probably need a second viewing in order to fill in the gaps in your mind as well as the questions that hit you time after time. What makes this film so great? Well the fact the story does nothing but puzzle you the entire 102 minutes. The last 2 minutes of the climax will leave most of your questions answered and you can lean back in your seat holding your head thinking "what a great movie that was, but I think I have to watch it again cos there was something I didn't quite understand".

Another thing is about the movie is the fact that no matter how many times you watch it, you always seem to pickup something you didn't quite understand or realize. The scenes don't get boring, the action doesn't just jump in at the opening scene, the films is filled with those catchy film dialogues that are nothing but great, and the climatic twist will leave most of you banging your heads with frustration because you had no idea what was coming to you. The well-chosen cast sinks into the plot and is so well constructed and believable that you're going to hope its all fiction. Are there a few words to describe this masterpiece? I like to believe there are a few for every movie. Ironic, suspenseful, mysterious, classic and cool. This film marked the beginning of a new perspective in the crime thrillers we all love to watch, and I strongly believe that it is a classic that we can all compare other movies too.

title: Well, only the best movie in existence.
review:
The Usual Suspects is not only a great movie but the best.

Original, thrilling, great acting, fantastic oscar winning screenplay

and most of all with an ending I will never forget. Spoiler: Just something to look at, the documents from Kobayashi

are handed out in the line as they are killed and the funniest thing

Swoon.....

title: Outstanding plot, brilliant actor´s performances
review: It tells the pretty complex story about a big robbery. There are five suspects for the crime and during the movie, everything gets far more complicated. The story is told by one of the suspects: the cripple Verbal Kint, which is played by Kevin Spacey. Spacey´s actor´s performance is so incredibly brilliant, that one would say he´s the leading star of the movie. But no: they all play brilliant! The actor´s performances of every single one person in this movie is really outstanding. The scene where Verbal walks into the office of the police officer, sits down and looks around is great! When you´ve seen the movie, you know why! As the story goes further, we learn that there´s one person who committed the crime: Keyser Soze. He´s a mythical person, who´s almost been never seen by anyone and is very, very dangerous. From that point on, the big question of the movie is: who of the suspects is Keyser Soze? So, the movie is a really `who did it' type of movie. Normally, those movies aren´t really original, but this one..really is original. The plot is one of the best I´ve ever seen and the ending is THE best ending I´ve ever seen. The most beautiful thing about it is that after watching it once, you want to watch it a second time immediately. The second time you watch it, you see it from a totally other perspective, because you know who did it. The acting is also in a double kind of way: some scenes can be interpreted in two ways (before and after you know). So, in sum, this movie is brilliant, one of the best ever. As a matter of fact, The Usual Suspects is rated 4th on my personal `best ever movies' list. Kevin Spacey is one of my most favourite actors, mainly for his acting in The Usual Suspects and American Beauty  (and let´s not forget The Negotiator and K-Pax). To people who didn´t see Usual Suspects jet: immediately run out of your house, get a copy and watch it, if you want to call yourself a movie lover, you really should´ve seen this one!!

title: Am I the only one?
review:
WARNING, SPOILERS

I have just seen this movie for the first time, and I loved it. Truly. But I was seeing the end coming from quite a while ago.

I mean, in this kind of movies with a "mistery man", the guilty one is usually the less predictable. So here we have a crippled man (who therefore cannot be a cruel, reckless, invincible assassin), who is the only survivor (except for the comma guy) and moreover, who is the one telling the story! I had some bells ringing over me...

In fact, I was quite surprised with the first pseudo-ending in which we are told that Keaton is Kayzer Soze. In the last interrogation scenes I was watching closely Kints' arm to see if he moved it, or switched his paralyzed side (he doesn't).

And I'm not one of those who always predict the endings. It didn't happen in other twist-end movies such as The 6th Sense, The Fight Club or The Others. Maybe today I was somehow inspired.

Nevertheless, I enjoyed this movie a lot and it surely deserves a high rating, let's say 8 over 10.

title: One of the best films of the last decade and all time too
review: I'd recommend you not to read this if you haven't seen this movie yet but to go to find it and to watch it. This movie is perfect. There are no flaws in this. Great acting, great directing, great writing. Simply perfect. This is a movie that you can watch every day and not get bored of it. I just can't imagine how at the hell this movie had such a small box office grossing.  Anyway I just want to tell those who are reading this to go and hire this masterpiece. You ain't gonna be dissapointed. I'm not going to talk about the film cause if I tell you the ending you'll probably wish I never did. 100/100

title: The greatest ending to a movie I have ever seen
review:
If you have never seen The Usual Suspects, watch it ASAP. The ending to this movie was shocking, moving, and put the largest grin on my face that I have ever had at the end of a movie. I have watched hundreds of classic movies and this movie without a doubt is one of the best I have ever seen.

Writing, Directing, Acting, and ESPICALLY the ending were all top notch.

title: The greatast mystery thriller ever made!
review: The Usual Suspects is a low budget master piece. With a cast of actors that screams class, and one of the most superbly written scripts, this film delivers the goods it should. Bryan Singer directs, and it is obvious this guy had a vision, he carries out the film with flairy class and creates a tense and gripping movie that come the end will leave you with your tongue hanging out in gormless dis-belief with a longing to watch the movie over and over again. The film starts out with the five central characters participating against their will in a line up, they are all criminals but are arrested seemingly on a trump charge and they need to figure out why, together in a cell they plot to do a job together, and not a job you could call in any way legal. This is in fact all being told by Kevin Spacey's character Verbal, the films actual setting is in a police detectives office as he is questionning Verbal about a slaughter on a boat where over 30 people were killed. The film is mainly told in flashbacks about the events leading up to Verbals interrogation. From the moment their first job is done things gradually build in pace and the air of mystery sets in. Kobayashi is a mysterious man played by Pete Postlethwaite, who claims he works for a guy called Kayzer Soze, a man who may or may not be a myth but who sends shivers down the spines of those who hear his name, rumours are even that this guy may be the devil himself, it turns out that all the five guys in someway owe mr Soze and are required to rob the boat of a large shipment of drugs, nobody knows who soze is but they are scared of him. The film is pure genius, full of twists and turns of which you could only guess by taking a wild stab in the dark. The music is atmospheric, and the way the film spans out is excellent, the director gives you plenty of clues as to the identity of Kayzer Soze and the film has so much depth to it and so many levels. The fact is you never quite know if verbal is telling the truth, we hear the happenings from his point of view but he may be exagerrating or bending the truth, its only the very end when things become clear. All the actors are great, Spacey was worthy of his oscar, and he really impresses here, also Gabriel Byrne is on top form too. Also I must say i'm not a big fan of Steven Baldwin, I've never been too impressed with his films especially the incredibly lame sequal to the Flintstones which in itself was lame, but in this Baldwin is very good as Macmanus the slightly nutty, gun happy criminal. Also Benicio Del Torro and Kevin Pollock have some good roles and most of the humour comes from them. This film is a must see, it has one of the greatest movie plot twists ever. 10/10

title: i am not keiser soze!
review:
Disclaimer - dont read if you havent seen!

Perhaps i imagined the whole thing... there i was, looking for the reasons i was there and they were right in front of me... the empty bottle of wine... the overturned ashtray... the half eaten pizza...

Where had I been? who had I been with? what had I done, ?

That was the feeling I had after my last night out. Much the same feeling as after watching 'The Usual Suspects.' Confusement long after the film ended.. it plagued me, hanging over me like the stale smell of beer!

Who WAS Keiser Soze?!

I still dont believe it was Verbal, the clues were all there yet we only ever hear the story from Verbal's point of view, in flash-back! (any 'goofs' spotters out there, i completely disagree that there are any since the story was completely from Verbal/Soze's p.o.v.)perhaps there wasnt never even a heist maybe the ship merely caught alight!

Was Verbal, Soze? Even Singer wont reveal that - that is what is so great about this film, it makes u think then think again, leaving the viewer to work out their own ending.

The mise-en-scene is so detailed from the very opening scene where the ropes light up in the shape of a devil in case you didnt notice and that shot then dissolves into Verbal, look above his head... devil horns? i think so!

Superb!

title: Jon Monsarrat review: Fantastic crime thriller
review:
Stop reading reviews and just go rent this film now. "The Usual Suspects" is an intellectual and superb crime thriller with plot twists and wonderful acting all around, especially by Kevin Spacey who packs an incredible acting punch in this film. I literally felt bowled over.

While it doesn't have "something to say that will change your life", nor does it explore deep themes particularly, there is a lot of high production value and art behind the characterizations and themes. But it doesn't get overly arty or melodramatic. The pace is fast throughout and the plot is tight and keeps you guessing.

Who should see this film:

-- action film buffs: a must-see, even if you aren't so sure

-- drama film buffs & arty types: safe for you

-- anybody else who's going to sample the occasional crime flick, this one's for you (or see "L.A. Confidential")

I'll give "The Usual Suspects" a 10 out of 10.

title: It'll blow you away!
review: The first time I saw The Usual Suspects I didn't enjoy it very much and I definitely didn't fully understand it.But the second time it was awesome. The end is awesome but it leaves a question in your mind: Then what really happened?

title: Yikes! Violence almost overwhelms picture
review:
After reading all of these reviews and seeing that it was rated as the ninth best movie EVER, I expected an awesome movie. What I got instead is a very violent (so violent, my wife quit watching after 45 minutes) movie which is good, but not great.

It's true that there is good acting, and also true that it is hard to guess the answers ahead of time. I did, but only a few minutes ahead of the movie. Once the violence stopped, I enjoyed the rest of the movie more. So I'm a wimp. Sue me. I think the violence was overdone and detracted from what might have been a more interesting plot + acting. I can see how people would be put off by the plot complexity, but I enjoyed it. It was nice to be able to rewind and look again.

title: A movie you can't see just once!
review: In the words of Fred Fenster, this movie, "will flip ya. Flip ya for real." It's raw, gritty and stylish. And you won't figure out what's going on before it's revealed to you.

title: watch this movie!

The twist in the plot completely throw you the first time you watch it, I've now seen the film 8 times after buying the box set.
