title: a dirty cop,a explosive expert,a cripple,2 thugs and the Devil
review: Sole survivor of the Long Beach bloodbath, "Verbal" Kint(Kevin Spacey) now in custody of U.S customs agent Kujan, tells an incredible tale about 91 millions dollars worth of cocaine, and a mysterious criminal by the name of Keyser Soze. In the same genre as "Shattered" or more recently "The Sixth Sense" the ending is were the punch is, Spacey turns one of it's best performance as the cripple Kint, witch by the way awarded him with a Oscar for best supporting actor, dubbed as one of the most stylish crime movie of the 90's "The usual Suspect" deserves more than one sitting, and should definitely be part of a collection.

title: Trust me - knowing the ending will not help you!SPOILERS
review: I've seen this film so many times I know the script almost by heart (even before I owned the screenplay).  With Gabriel Byrne and Kevin Spacey in it they frankly could have been reading the telephone directory as far as I was concerned but when I saw this movie for the first time I was so utterly blown away by its bravado that I really did not know what had hit me. Trust me - knowing the ending will not help you one jot!  I say this knowing that spoilers are a no-no in IMDBland.  This is such an utterly ambiguous movie that you will watch it and be convinced of every one of its twists and turns as they are presented.  And then you will get to the end, start analysing what you 'think' you have seen and realise that the 'holes' in the final version you think you have gotten the gist of floats away from you like paper tissue in a strong wind.  As the film ends two great re-iterations of lines from its script, I can think of no better way to end this review: "The greatest trick the Devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't exist......And like that, he's gone..."

title: Benicio must love Monk.
review:
A lot of people liked "The Usual Suspects". I have to admit, I was one of them. But when I happened to view the movie again a few weeks ago, something struck me that for whatever reason did not the first time.

During the interrogation scene near the beginning of the film, the cops are trying to shake down Benicio Del Toro's character, Fred Fenster. One of the responses that Fenster gives is "It will flip you, I mean flip you for real." My jaw immediately hit the floor. The line, the mannerisms, the timing were all taken from the quasi-documentary about Thelonious Monk's life, "Straight, No Chaser." Check out the Monk film and you will find not only the line, verbatim, in a restaraunt scene, but you will also see most of the mannerisms that Del Toro used in "Usual Suspects."

This rather obvious homage to one of my favorite musicians made me like Del Toro a bit more. Maybe it will inspire fans of "The Ususal Suspects" to check out the film on Monk and perhaps listen to some of the best music this country has to offer.

title: Not the most intelligent, but definitely one of the best, with a nice twist in the end!
review:
I would say that this movie certainly belongs to the "intelligent movie" genre. And I have to say that it is one of the best movies in that genre aswell. Though not the most intelligent, not to say that it is not intelligent, but absolutely, the trickiest movie. It really got me fooled.

As you can tell by my nick, it is no secret that I really care for this film. It is not only the story that makes it so great and honorable, but all the actors and the director contributes aswell. I mean, Bryan Singer chosed a great actor/actress for every single character worth noticing in this film. Just take a look at the line-up.

It is not easy to write a comment on this movie because I am afraid I would give away too much. But believe me, even though it may seem a bit slow to some people, it is really worth the wait, because you will never get a better ending in a movie, than you will get in this one. Trust me.

If you have not seen The Usual Suspects, do it now!

title: One of the greatest crime dramas of all time.
review:
Dark, spooky, full of shadowy images and shady characters, "The Usual Suspects" is, quite simply, one of the greatest crime dramas ever made. The writing is sublime, the acting magnificent and the score is top-notch, all of which contribute to create a taut, tense thriller in which five hardened criminals are rounded up and dropped into a situation in which they are not only way over their heads, but from which there is no escape. Kevin Spacey's Oscar-winning portrayal of crippled con artist Verbal Kint is masterful and truly well-deserved.

The entire story is told almost completely in flashback, as Kint relates the story of the death of his partners, and the events of the six weeks leading up to it, to the police who are interrogating him. At first evasive and vague, Kint begrudgingly hints to the existence of a faceless, seemingly omnipresent criminal mastermind, who goes by the (great) name of Keyser Soze. Soze is painted as a master criminal and manipulator who is behind every facet of the tragedy of the death of Kint's partners.

For those of you reading this review who have not actually seen the film, and do not know about the "twist" ending, I will only say this: I NEVER SAW IT COMING. The moment of clarity that comes just too late is probably the single greatest moment in a truly remarkable film.

In a recent poll by Entertainment Weekly, "The Usual Suspects was ranked #2 (just behind "Shawshank Redemption") in the category "Best Film to Watch Over and Over Again", and rightly so. This film simply does not get old.

If you are a crime drama fan, you MUST make this film a part of your library. It deserves to be ranked right up there among the classics of Humphrey Bogart and James Cagney.

title: THE BEST MOVIE OF ALL ETERNITY!!!
review:
This movie deserves the Oscar for "Film That May Never be Matched." Or something like that. I'll keep this brief, but I'll make all of my points. First, what was good.

What wasn't good?! Kevin Spacey was as expected, which is Oscar worthy, Benicio Del Toro was unbelievable. (Sidenote: In the original script, Fenster is quite boring in comparison to the character that Del Toro created for the film.) Gabriel Byrne was great, Stephen Baldwin was great (which is remarkable.) Kevin Pollak was great. Pete Postlethwaite was perfect. Chazz Palmienteri was great. Whoever I'm leaving out was great. Bryan Singer did agreat job directing, and Christopher McQuarrie, well...what can you say about him? This script must be the best I've ever.

The ONLY thing that COULD have been better, was the lighting. I thought the film might have been better if it were a little darker, but I may be wrong. Either way it turned out to be a classic that I will force my children and grand-children to watch over and over again.

TEN OUT OF TEN!!!

title: Response to some previous reviewers
review:
===SPOILERS, DON'T READ IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THE MOVIE==> One previous review faulted The Usual Suspects because Verbal Kint's story is presented as factual, not as just a story...whoever that reviewer was, you missed the entire point of the movie. Kint's story WAS factual, all of it was true. He only made up new names to protect himself and Kobayashi. For example, the name Redfoot appears on one poster. If Kint had used the fence's real name, detectives later on could have found Redfoot, interrogated him to find Kobayashi (we assume that is the employee of Soze that Redfoot did business with), and in turn they could have gotten to Soze himself. Kint also used the cork board to make up the stories about the barbershop quartet and the coffee in Guatemala, that was just to fill in useless chatter (he is named Verbal...we see even Soze has a sense of humor) and make himself look stupid and innocent to the detective. But the rest of his testimony really happened.

Another reviewer said that the movie doesn't give enough hints and clues as to the ending, and listed The Sixth Sense and Fight Club as better examples of movies with surprise endings. First of all, the Sixth Sense and Fight Club made it TOO obvious, any moron could figure out the "surprise" halfway through. These movies would be absolutely nothing without the ending. Hell, they were horrible even with the ending. As for the clues, there were a few subtle hints in the Usual Suspects that pop up watching the movie a second time. There is Soze's pseudonym Verbal, which I have already mentioned. Also, in the sequence where they are conducting the assault on the boat, at one point Kint is standing behind one of his friends, I forget which, and his friend is trying to determine what language the people on the boat are speaking. He has no idea, but Kint immediately says "Hungarian". How would a stupid thug living in America recognize the Hungarian language? Kint knows it is Hungarian because he is Kaiser Soze, a criminal who had his beginnings in Hungary. Another clue is when Kint is waiting in the detective's office, and the detective is talking with his coworker outside. His coworker tells him that Kint is "protected from up high by the Prince of Darkness." It is curious that a stupid, gimped, small-time criminal would have this much influence.

In conclusion, I think that The Usual Suspects is a complex, but entirely plausible story who's surprise ending enhances the rest of the story, instead of serving as the only attraction, as in The Sixth Sense and Fight Club. After seeing the Usual Suspects once, I instantly bought it on video and have enjoyed watching the entire film again and again.

title: One of the best films of the 90's
review:
I remember not expecting a whole lot out of this one...but WOW. Immediately I was so amazed by the excitement and mystery. This movie does something really interesting:

You think you know what's going to happen...it seems crazy, and you want it to be true...but it doesn't seem possible. And when you see you were right, it's the most incredible feeling.

I have only stood and cheered once in my life, and it was *this* movie! If you haven't seen it...see it. Everyone in this movie is incredible. You know how sometimes you say, "I wish Tom Hanks had played this guy instead..." This movie will not make you think that, the casting was perfect and the performances near flawless...

review: This film is amazing it will blow you away. It is my fav film of all time over Shawshank Redemption, Pulp Fiction or any of the other 'greats'. Everything about this film is amazing, watch it and you will agree.

title: brilliant, but no replay value
review: Given the rest of the comments on this site, I will refrain from waxing loquacious, and simply say that I enjoyed this film immensely for its suspense, its wonderful cast, and the way that it completely captured me until the very last second.  Unfortunately I will never see this film again by myself, because that one question, "Who is Kaiser Soze(sp?)?" sets the suspense level for the entire movie, and knowing the answer, it is not possible to watch it again and enjoy it as much, except in the company of people who haven't seen it, during which you are watching THEIR reactions to the film rather than the film itself.

title: This movie will leave your jaw on the floor
review: Quite possibly one of the most incredible movies of all time, every single actor gives a performance never to be forgotten, especially Kevin Spacey, nervous, not too bright, but what you don't believe is that he's the King of the Universe, that is until you find out what a phenomenal Liar he is, and how when you're a Mastermind Criminal, you better be as cunning as cold blooded as He is.

title: Wonderful beyond words.
review: All I can say is that this is the only movie with a plot twist (there have been so many) pulled off so well it actually made me gasp out loud. The effect it was trying to pull went off without a hitch: I sat there for the first hour and 45 minutes confused and bewildered, got to the (first) twist and though "oh, well...I get it now" and was then completely blind-sided by the (real) twist which knocked me on my ass. It was great - and every person I've forced to watch this film has had the same reaction exactly...followed my an immediate urge to watch it again. And again.

title: Best movie ever.
review: This movie is seriously in the top ten on my list of best movies ever. Kevin Spacey is superp and spactacular. Gabriel Byrne is moving. This is the movie that made Benicio del Toro famous. Chazz Palminteri does an excellent job. This is the best written movie(with the exception of Pulp Fiction)ever. The cast is filled with spectacular actors. Stephen Baldwin and Kevin Pollack make excellent criminals. The story and movie is riveting. You won't know the answer to the riddle until the very end. It is the best movie ever(in my opinion) a must see.

title: So much more than a thriller
review:
The day after I saw this at the cinema, I went to see it again. I just couldn't believe what my eyes had told me was there on the screen, and I needed to see how writer and director had pulled off one of the finest tricks in recent movie history.

This is so much more than a thriller. Ultimately, it's a meditation about film and the nature of story telling. Just what is real, what can be authenticated, and where do history and fiction stop and start? As the movie ends in a puff of backlit smoke, it reminds us that all movies are just that - light.

The Usual Suspects recently had its TV premier here in the UK. After imploring my friends to watch it for the past few years, there are still some who haven't seen it. My campaign continues.

If you're still one of the unfortunates, tear up that list of your Top Twenty movies. You'll need to create a new spot in there somewhere.

title: it was keyser soze!
review: when kevin spacey is involved you know it's going to be good, one of my all time favorite movies, full of smart dialog, and some great action scenes, great acting from everyone involved, it's not for those people who have to figure out (or the world will end) who did it before the movie is over, or those people who think they could have given the movie a better ending (make your own movie!), this is for people who love movies and can just let themselves get into the story, and enjoy it. after a police line up puts  five cons together, they decide to start doing some jobs, the last one is an assault on a boat, after that goes wrong, the survivors are left to tell the story, the spacey character tells his side of the story to a police detective, (but is he feeding him just a bunch of bull sh**?), his story takes a turn when the name of keyser soze is mentioned by the only other survivor, who is keyser soze?, is keyser soze the devil himself?, apparently it was he who arranged the assault, but why? no one knows for sure, the detective is sure he figured out the motives and the identity of the keyser and confronts spacey with that information, after all is said and done, the detective finally realizes his mistake, but does he still have a chance to capture the keyser?, no it's too late!, because just like that, he's gone.

title: Who is Keyser Soze?
review: This was an incredibly cool film, with great characters and a great plot. One of its best points is the frightening villain, Keyser Soze, who is never truly seen, but still brings a chilling and mysterious tone to the movie. I have heard many call this film boring, which could be true since the film is literally talking. But, when you think of the 'jobs' that the team pull off throughout the movie, such as an ambush on a taxi service of crooked cops, an attack against a rich man and his two bodyguards, and one of my all time favorite action sequences, an all scale assault on the boat (Including McManus with a sniper rifle, Hockney with a machine gun, and Keaton with two automatic pistols). This film has such great characters, you can always find a favorite. There is also some comedy ("Big fat guy, I mean like Orca fat.") thrown in to keep you interested. Overall, this film is one of my favorites, and is a must see.

title: The best crime thriller since the great days of film-noir
review:
I watched this in a hotel room early in the morning after jet-lag woke me up. I sat on the end of the bed and started the film, intending to go out to the vending machine for a drink at some point. An hour later I managed to grab a glass of water, but otherwise I hardly moved.

Brilliant ensemble performances, twisty plot, blink and you'll miss it action. The final action scene is a little drawn out, but otherwise this film is close to perfect.

title: fantastic
review:
a plot going nowhere it seems and suddenly, within 5 minutes, everything is clear, and u think, oh gosh did they make it that way. absolutely. thats the most striking thing about it. its not an obvious movie. its different, unique, beautiful at places, and out and out suspenseful. ofcourse, that is, if u understand it. i kept pacing with the movie. never heard of the ending from anyone. and things just got messier and then, boom!, everything was so obvious.

beautifully written. beautifully directed. the cast was perfect (though i thought if al-pacino had been in place of gabriel, it was an instant 9.9, but even then maybe 9.5 from me). kevin spacey was absolutely fantastic.

some ppl didnt understand this movie, thus they didnt like it. i dunno, i loved it. one of the all time greats.

title: Superb crime movie
review:
The Usual Suspects is simply a great movie. From it's unique and wonderful directing style to it's great cast of charcaters and actors, The Usual Suspects is just one good scene after another that compiles together to form a modern masterpiece in crime drama.

All of the actors were just spectacular in this picture. Stephen Baldwin is just great. He's funny and plays a great criminal. Kevin Pollack, ome of the most underrated and talented actors of our time, is hilarious. He plays the regular wise-cracking jerk criminal full of good jokes and fresh sarcasm. Kevin Spacey is phenomenal. He acts perfectly for the role he is supposed to. Benicio Del Toro is great too. He's funny and exciting in all of his roles, of course. And of course there's Chazz Palmenteri. He's great as the hard-ass detective trying desperately to solve the mystery the film centers around.

The non-linear order of scenes in this movie really works out well, and is never really confusing. Non-linear timelines of scenes always add a little spice to the film. This one works out perfectly.

And of course the plot is just awesome. It's a great story for a crime/drama. Twists and turns at every corner. Surprises, fun elements added, etc. The action in the movie is great too. The gun fighting scenes are good too.

Last but definitely not least is the great ending. Bryan Singer just pulls the carpet out from under you. It's surprising and simply awesome. And the ending scenes are truly classic. Truly. This is just a great film that deserves to be seen by everybody.

title: UNUSUAL, BUT A REAL CHEAT
review:
Bryan Singer's "The Usual Suspects" is a good thriller, but how much you enjoy it will depend on personal taste. It has good acting (especially Kevin Spacey, who won an Oscar for this role), but it gets bogged down by it's plot and the ending is a real cheat.

Roughly, the film is one giant enigma: "Who is Keyser Soze?" We find the detective trying to figure out what happened during a heist gone bust: his only lead is Verbal Kint (Spacey) who weaves a tale of intrigue, double cross and even more questions than could possibly be answered during the rather short running time (108 minutes, it should have been about 30 minutes longer).

Ultimately, the film is all style, but very little substance. Style can be a good thing: look at Brian DePalma's best films (Dressed to Kill, Body Double, Blow Out, Obsession). "The Usual Suspects" has an ending very similar to "Dressed to Kill", but Singer can't pull it off the way DePalma did. It just can't be believed.

But the ultimate letdown of the film is hardly Singer's fault: he does an excellent job of directing a rather choppy and labyrinthine script and he does it with such style and grace (along with Spacey's performance) that I find myself recommending the film despite my reservations.

If you like to be confused and enjoy solving puzzles (like me), you'll like, maybe even love, "The Usual Suspects". But even those kinds of people will be compelled to say "ENOUGH!" after an hour and 20 minutes of this film.

*** out of 4 stars

title: cheap-thrill ending
review: I remember when I was a kid writing stories. If I couldn't think of a good ending, you know what I'd do? Have the main character wake up in a state of heartbeating sweaty relief: Thank god it was only a dream... And you know what? The usual suspects has the exact same type of ending. The reason it is cheap is that this ending could be attatched to any movie whatsoever. There was nothing tying it together with the rest of the entire movie besides maybe a few seconds of Spacey looking at the police corkboard. If you want to do a surprise ending, you need to have evidence throughout the movie to tie it together. Examples are fight club and the sixth sense, regardless of their other merits, they definitely did the surprise ending the right way. You could watch the movie a second time and get have an entirely new experience. All along you're saying, "ohhhhh, I get it now. That's why he did that." Usual Suspects was not a great surprise ending movie, but it did have some respectable dialogue and characters. 7 of 10.

title: Best crime movie. Ever.
review:
(spoilers) The Usual Suspects is one of those rare movies that comes along and takes advantage of all of the expectations that audiences develop as a result of an overabundance of formula films. One of the things that really sets The Usual Suspects apart from other crime films is that it has an excellent story, but it is also very uniquely presented. The whole film is told in a series of flashbacks by Verbal Kint, performed flawlessly by Kevin Spacey. The script has the rare quality of being extremely intricate but also very involving, you never get lost despite the tremendous amount of detail that the story has.

(spoilers) Benecio Del Toro shows up in one of his earlier roles as Fred Fenster, the character that, as Brad Pitt has stated, makes it okay to be incomprehensible (Fenster influenced Pitt's performance in the excellent film Snatch). Gabriel Byrne is the perfect actor to play the part of Dean Keaton, the usual suspect who doesn't quite fit in with the rest and who is temporarily revealed to be the fearful Keyser Sosey. Stephen Baldwin makes a good criminal, and his performance is very effective. And Kevin Pollack did a very good job as well. On a trivial point, you'll notice that Keaton's hotel room in The Usual Suspects is the same room that was used as Quentin Tarantino's hotel room in the hilarious black comedy, Four Rooms.

The ending of The Usual Suspects has become known to be one of the best endings to a film in years, especially because of the shock value. Not only is it entirely unexpected, but it also reveals the ingenuity of the script, especially when we realize that Verbal fabricated the entire story, using names and locations that he simply read off of the wall in the room of the police station where he was interrogated. This ending has become famous enough to be re-created in a number of spoof movies. It was very amusingly done in Wrongfully Accused, but unnecessarily done in the idiotic Scary Movie. The Usual Suspects is an excellent film. It has great performances, good direction, and a flawlessly presented story. It's too bad that it's so rare for a movie to have so much thought put into it, so it's nice to see one come along every once in a while that just seems to do everything right.

title: No.1 Thriller!!
review: I loved the suspense of this movie and it really took me for a thrill ride. I would recommend you to watch this movie as it defines the art of film making, script writing and acting. Kevin Spacey plays an excellent role in this movie and truly brings the qualities necessary in the character.

title: A gripping movie....then the ending....wow
review: This was a gripping movie...I have never been glued to the screen as I was when I saw this...I didn't see this movie until 2000 when I got it for £5 for my local video store...The best £5 I have ever spent...My girlfriend liked this movie although she fell asleep before the ending so she never worked it all out..lol

title: Film making at it's best
review:
Having seen The Usual Suspects I have been telling my friends all about it. They prefer to watch dumb action films rather than 'talking' films. The Usual Suspects is a 'talking' film but the script and directing is so good that it is an instant classic.

It tells the story of five criminals brought together in a line up and decide to do some jobs together after their release. These Usual Suspects do a variety jobs with great success. This is all told by cripple Verbal Kint (Oscar winner Kevin Spacey) in flashbacks. As the story builds the question is, Who is Keyser Soze?

Singer handles the movie perfectly and the writing by Christopher McQuarrie is first class. As for the other actors they all give brilliant support. Stephen Baldwin plays psycho McManus, Gabriel Byrne is ex-cop Keaton, Benicio Del Toro is McManus' partner Fenster and Kevin Pollack is weapons expert Todd Hockney.

The film has an unbelievable ending which has to be seen to be believed. The Usual Suspects is one of the greatest movies ever!

title: A must have for any video collection
review:
This movie was absolutely incredible, I own it, have seen it a hundred times, and will never get tired of it.

Kevin Spacey gives one of the performances of his life, and is backed by an amazing cast, including Gabriel Byrne, Benicio Del Toro before he was famous, Stephen Balwin in what is definitely the best role of his career, and Kevin Pollak, who is consistently hilarious. It features amazing dialogue, sound editing, and I won't give away the ending, but it is honestly the best thing I've ever seen. Chazz Palminteri is perfect as the cocky FBI agent, Dan Hedaya is on target as a NYC cop, and Pete Postlethwaite riveting. There is nothing bad you can say about this film. It's too bad Christopher McQuarrie wrote such a lackluster script for his more recent film, The Way of the Gun.

The plot twist that ends this movie is great even if you are looking for it, but when it surprises you, as it surprised me, it is absolutely astounding. The theatre emitted a huge "ohmigod" when the film came to its final 15 minutes. The audience realizes what's happened as the characters do, and thus are drawn right into the movie. This is the most original way to reveal a twist EVER. An absolutely original story, and worth it for the great performances alone. Rent it!

title: The most compulsive viewing film I have seen. The music was real edge of seat stuff.
review: It certainly helped,  watching the making of "The Usual Suspects" prior to watching the movie.  Although it did throw even more doubts into the identity of "Kaiser Soze". Was it intentional that the image of "Kaiser Soze" descending the ladder on the ship was reminiscent of Orson Wells descent into the Viennese sewers in "The Third Man".

title: Suspects, but not guilty
review:
The Usual Suspects is very different from the 99% of the films which are released every year. The difference lays on the fact that this film is an original piece of art. As Citizen Kane or The Godfather, this film proves that entertainment and quality can be combined, in fact, that they should be combined. Because when we are in a cinema watching a film we expect something more than guns shooting or explosions. We want the film to make us think, and even more, to surprise us. Because this is what cinema is all about. Unfortunately most of the films try to make this by means of endings which are very hard to believe, or by making a film visually strong. The Usual Suspects is very far from all that. The script of this film is one of the most brilliant ever written, but even more important, it's original. Because when seeing this film you realize you have never seen something like this before, and probably will never see it again.

The film is a very intelligent and complex thriller with a mixture of characters that confuse you until the end of the film. Still you are all the time asking yourself what is happening. It is only when you see it again that you realize that not only the plot is really good, but that the dialogues are excellent. This film is probably one of the films with more brilliant quotes. At the same time the actors are excellent, especially the five suspects. All this makes The Usual Suspects one of the best and most interesting films ever.

title: Great; could have been greater.
review:
This movie should have been titled "Keyser Soze." Like eponymous prop in "The Maltese Falcon", Soze isn't even mentioned until halfway through the movie but he comes to dominate everything and everyone. Instead, we start off with the five title characters but soon it's not their story. It's almost as if it were the start of one move and the last half (but not the end) of another.

The movie never lets up in building tension and new twists. Events pile up on top of one another until every one is caught up in Soze's net. You can almost see writer Christopher McQuarrie bahing on the keys and then stopping & asking himself, "and THEN what?!"

Still, I have to wonder about that line "The gretest trick the devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't exist." It's great but it sticks out like a sore thumb. If that's supposed to be a film-noir throwback (the great era for lines) then the rest of the dialogue should have supported it, or a wise-crack like in the film-noir era or it should have been the unspoken subtext.

Whatever your opinion on that line or the twist ending, you can't deny that McQuarrie earned his Oscar nor Spacey his.

title: a true gem
review:
This movie seems unwatchable at first, but give it time. (namely, about 10 minutes.) It gets better...then better...then even better...then watch out!

Kevin Spacey deserved his oscar for this movie, and it will give you something to talk about for a few days after you see it. Try to observe all the clues, and the ending will getcha. I enjoyed it and recommend it to anyone who likes crime movies and/or Kevin Spacey.

*** out of ****

title: Gripping, nearly perfect, crime saga
review:
Much to the surprise of my fellow co-workers, I had not yet seen The Usual Suspects nearly six years after its theatrical release. The animated discussion of the movie around the water cooler was instantly suspended so as not to give away any crucial plot elements. Intrigued, I ran across the street to the video store and rented the film immediately.

Well worth the price of admission. A nearly perfect film. Kevin Spacey gives the performance of a lifetime, completely deserving of the Academy Award he earned. The All Star cast is to be commended for a job well done.

The plot of the movie unfolded so intriguingly, and the Tarantino-esque style in which it is presented provides for an entertaining movie-watching experience.

It is unfortunate that, in spite of all my efforts to the contrary, I guessed the ending of the film, long before it unfolded on screen. This perhaps detracted from the overall viewing pleasure, but did not diminish the superior quality of the film itself.

The less you know about this movie, the better. Run, quickly, to a video store near you and rent this movie before you learn too much.

You'll thank me later.

title: "And like that...poooof! He was gone!..Vanished into thin air.."
review:
"The Usual Suspects" is a movie which most reviewers advise to watch very carefully. "Don't go to the bathroom or move to get popcorn.." they say. It is crafted as a semi-narrative story in which we learn about the experiences of 5 criminals who band together to get even with a careless police department. They do not know, however, that they are being manipulated by a notorious Hungarian psychopath named "Keyser Sosey".

The first time you see this movie you see it the way Keyser Sosey wants you to see it. It will surprise you. The second time you see it (which Ebert also had to do), you will be seeing it from a different perspective. The second time, you will, perhaps, see it from the perspective of the investigator who was grilling and intimidating Verbal Kint (lone survivor of a burned ship and 29 dead bodies). It will surprise you again. Both times you see it, you will be gathering more information of what was done and why. The third time you see it, you'll probably drop your coffee cup on the floor and it will shatter.

I rate this movie a "10", and if you don't see it...Well, let's just say Keyser Sosey might have a message for you.

Jack Hamann

title: This film is built to be seen twice!
review:
I've seen a number of reviews on this movie and most of them admit that it is a movie that you must pay attention to. "The Usual Suspects" does have some interesting twists and turns to it which you have to keep up with. The main focus for me was figuring out who "Kaiser Soze'" was and how he was important to the plot. At the end of the movie after listening to Mr. Kints ad-libbing to a bully-detective, you will drop your coffee cup to the ground and it will shatter! Then, when you watch the movie for the second time from a totally different point of view, you will realize that this movie has been brilliantly crafted as a work of dramatic art. Kevin Spacey's performance is fantastic!

Jack Hamann

title: Very good
review: Everyone knows about the twist, but I won't give it away for those who don't. Difficult to get into it at the beginning, but it is worth it. Spacey really deserved his Oscar here. One of the best films of the 90's.8/10

title: The not so usual movie
review:
What can I say. After I saw this movie I was blown away. My Jaw Dropped. I couldn't believe my eyes. I was speechless. I said to myself that I could never see another movie again for the rest of my life because I cant imagine anything can top that.

The movie had a great cast, incredible acting, terrific directing, an unbelievable plot, which just all acopolated to the greatest movie ever.

When I want to see the movie I was a little resistant. It sounded kind of corny. At the time I didn't really know who any of the actors were. The only reason I went to see it was because it was recommended to me by a friend who's opinion I deeply respect( And even more so now). But let me tell you it was utmost definitely worth the hour and forty-two minutes of my time.

It was not the usual crime drama, but I like the fact that it was a little different. Although slow at times it all became worth it at the end. And I will say no more on this movie because I don't want to ruin it for you . But definitely go see it.

If you like this movie I also recommend "The Sea Of Love" w/ Al Pacino.

title: Best Film Ever!!!!!!
review: This is the most tightly crafted film ever written.  Every time you see it, you notice little details that you never noticed before.  The ending is a total surprise, and it leaves you with a tingly feeling all over.  I highly recommend this film to everyone.

title: The best surprise ever
review: Even when Spacey makes an exit after taking the gold lighter and watch there are chances that you may get the clue. But you are so caught up in the whole process of Verbal's narration that the end comes like one of those big surprises that make you realize there's not going to be another film like this.

title: This movie rocks!
review: Whoa!  This movie was a mind-blowing action thriller, and I can't recommend it enough to anyone in the mood for a great crime thriller/mystery. (SPOILERS)  I loved all the intricate plot elements, such as Verbal Kint being Keyser Soze, and all of the other guys being duped into killing the snitch who was about to tell the customs agents about Soze and his operations.  All in all, a truly awesome film!  If you haven't seen it, you haven't lived, baby! Rating: 10/10

title: Best Movie of the Year
review: This is by far the best movie I saw in 95 and one of the best movies I have ever seen.  The plot is thick and intricate, pulling the viewer into the web of Keyser Soze, whose identity is known to none.  This film is a neo-noir reminiscent of the 1940s crime thrillers.  The characters are well drawn and very real.  This is by far one of the best mysteries.  Every time I watch it, I pull something else out of this movie that I have never seen before, and I have watched this movie about 50 times. ~Alycia

title: Best movie ever!
review: This is the only movie ever I found worth to go to in an Theatre twice! Kevin Spacey delivers, together with an all star cast. The storyline is unbelievable and if you have guessed (without knowing in advance) the outcome, you are psychic! (Go make a living ripping off people.) You just have got to see this movie, and tell all your friends.

title: Pure Brilliance!
review: What can be said about this fantastic film that hasn't already been said. It has a stunning, superb acting and one of the cleverest endings to a film. The story can get a bit confusing some of the time but you will still enjoy it. This film deserves all the credit it gets! 10/10

title: confusing
review: I liked it the first time I saw it, then when I thought about it, nothing made sense.  O.K., lets say Kevin Spacey's character made up the whole thing, then how come he includes Chazz P(the cop he's talking to) in his story.  What if we all could figure the plot out?  Does it really matter? Should we waste our time figuring out a stupid, confusing plot?  At the end we're left with two great performances, (Spacey and Del Toro) and nothing else, because the filmmakers' main interests are in plot.

title: Can't get any better than this
review: Wow... The Usual Suspects is definetely the best crime/police movie ever. It's absolutely brilliant, as plot, acting, directing, editing... everything. But the best of all is the fabulous Kevin Spacey, an actor that never ceases to amaze me. He plays superbly the role of Verbal Kint, one of the 5 guys. The movie is awesome, and the way the story is told reminds me a little bit of Tarantino. This is definetely a must for everyone. Still doesn't have the originality to deserve a 10. So my vote: 9.

title: Spacey is god
review:
Gabriel Byrne, Benicio Del Toro, Kevin Pollak, Stephen Baldwin and Pete Postlethwaite. Every actor identified in this film performs unbelievably well. As with the actors in Reservoir Dogs (Especially Steve Buscemi and Michael Madsen), this piece is probably the finest work that many of them will ever do. Bryan Singer's direction is amazing considering the time and budget restrictions. Chris McQuarrie's writing is also brilliant, even down to the small comments and dialogue of Fenster, Hockney and McManus.

One of the greatest films ever made! and I didn't even mention Kevin Spacey.

10/10

title: a really good throwback to film noir...
review: In the midst of the film noir revival that seems to have been sparked by the success of PULP FICTION, THE USUAL SUSPECTS turns out to be a really, really good movie with a strong script and strong performances. Most impressive, however, is the style in which it is filmed- it truly is a work of film noir, bested only by SWOON in it's deft handling of sticky, dark subject material, unlikely and unlikeable heroes, black humor and ultimately disturbing, edgy portraits of violence and the psychology of violence. Though in color, it still manages to maintain that dark, oppressive feeling of shadows and depression so essential to films of this nature, and the ending, even if you're not surprised (or someone told you what it was before you saw the film- as happened to me)is incredibly well executed and totally satisfying.

title: Incredible
review: This movie is the most thought provoking, utterly incredible to date, I believe.  The different ways one can view this film are almost limitless. The camera angles amazing and the lighting superb.  The directing is some of the best to date and the characters are played to perfection.  Verbal is the most sinister and ingenious character in a movie ever.  He dumbs down every character in the film and they never even realize it.

title: Incredible!!!
review: I consider myself a smart movie-viewer, often upsetting those watching films with me because I expose the ending of many movies as we watch.  I just hate it when a plot plays out predictably.  Without saying too much to spoil the climax of this film, let's just say that I was totally surprised and totally thrilled with the way the filmmaker took us through this story and then hit us with the ending to end all great film endings.  Masterful.  See this movie now to be blown away.  Then watch it again to pick up all the clues that the director drops in along the way...

title: the most stellar flick ive come across
review:
this movie is overflowing with so many amazing things its not even funny... the ever-twisting plot brings a mind-boggling "be your own detective" interactive feel to the movie that is unsurpassed in any film...

the acting is pheonomenal. obviously, kevin spacey is one of the most talented actors around these days, every character in the movie, no matter how minute, is played with an incredibly unique and distinct fire... i especially loved McManus and Keaton...

as for filming.. it creates a confusiong atmosphere with its editing and interesting shots that often involve only parts of the storyline as they're slowly unveiled... its great

there isn't a thing that i can find to hate about this movie.. its my odds-on favorite right now... and i think if you give it a chance its well worth the time

title: what a plot!
review:
I saw this movie & i was thunder struck...like.. what a plot this movie has! In the last 2 minutes, u get to understand what a hoax of a story it was... a real shocker.

Kevin spacey outdoes himself yet again. I saw his 'Seven' & thought, "this guy can really act". Then i see this & i think,"I love this guy". Kevin is not making any bad choices..definitely.

In the movie, everything is so dark,efficient & sinister in a clean, white sort of way. They know what they r doing, or rather, he knows what he's saying...what a smooth lier this guy is.

All thumbs up for these ppl & the director. As far as movies with a great plot are concerned, this one definitely & without a doubt, takes the cake.

title: Top ten of all time
review: This film was one of the freshest Film's of the 1990's.  The film sets up 5 underdogs against a backdrop of espionage, the crimal underworld and a $90m hit on a Trukish trawler. The casting is magnificent, can you imagine what would have happended if these guys were established stars, the film would have lost credibity, and clouded objective opinion. The dialogue is mixed and is underpinned by a wise-guy street mentality. The story is narrated after-the-fact by verbal kent.  What amazes is the narration is sustatined to the very end, and the more unbelievable his story is, the more believable it is.  It is testimony to the writers/directors of this film to take what is believed and ensured throughout the film and destroyed and reworked in the denouement.  As is put so chillingly, "the greatest trick the devil ever pulled was convincing the world he didn't exist", "and like that he's gone." 10/10

title: First for fun, second for art
review:
This is the greatest movie I've ever seen. First time I've watched it with my two friends. A day after that all of us has brought about ten friends to this fable. A day after that the cinema was full with our friends. A day after that the cinema had to introduce an extra showing time especially for us...

Some thousands later The Usual Suspect has been released on video. Thankfully. The cinema can close now. :)

Whatch it for fun for the first time. And you will return for art for the second time.

And one other thing: the Hungarians aren't that mean guys as described. Believe me! I'm a Hungarian.

And I DO fear from K.S.

title: The best movie I have ever seen, bar none.
review: A masterpiece of complexity and misdirection.  It takes several viewings to figure how carefully the viewer is led astray.  Beautiful double-take ending.  A perfectly excellent movie.  Best I've ever seen.  17 on a scale of 10.

title: Wow...what a film...
review: One day, I was at college in a Media Studies lesson and I turned to the lad next to me, nameably Richard 'The Legend' Davies and I said 'This is boring, seen any good films recently?'.  He smiled and then said 'Oh God, yeah'.  I asked about what film it was and he replied with 'It's called 'The Usual Suspects' directed by Bryan Singer'.  Now, Rich had decent taste in films as his favourites were 'The Godfather' and 'The Shawshank Redemption'.  I took his recommendation of the film and hired it out that very night.  Amazed is one way to describe my feeling towards the film as soon as I had finished watching it.  Since then I've been out and bought it and it has become a great favourite of mine.  What can be said that hasn't already been said about how good Kevin Spacey is?  He is absolutely brilliant in this and is supported superbly by a variety of actors such as Pete Posthelwaite, Gabriel Byrne, Benicio Del Toro and Stephen Baldwin (Who I thought was a tosser before I saw this and realised how good he is!).  This film has slowly but surely made it's way into my Top 10 films of all time.  I recently was given the screenplay free at university and I have just finished reading it and it's just as good!  This truely is a fantastic film and one to be watched over and over again.

title: never will there be a movie such as this
review: I am unfortunately reduced to 1000 words in commenting on this movie because i could seriously go on for days.  I love this movie.  It is my hands-down favourite movie of all time.  It is intelligent, suspenseful, dramatic, beautifully acted (kevin spacey, kevin spacey, kevin spacey - and a seriously incredible supporting cast!) and one of the more original ideas of the past 5 years.  Many followers came and they fell - hard! The idea of five criminals (short, tall, physically challenged - great variety!) working for the big guy - the crime kingpin himself, whom every criminal has heard of, is so cool.  I mean, you think: is there really a big criminal kingpin that all baddies know and fear?  man oh man, i am salivating just thinking about it.  i think i will go watch it again.  My suggestion is to buy it on dvd, it is cheap and the film commentary by the directors is really cool and gives you some neat trivia.  Until next time...

title: Awesome movie.
review: I thought that this was one of the more original movies I'd ever seen. It kept the viewer in suspense, the acting was amazing, the plot was great, and Kevin Spacey really established himself as an A-rank talent with this movie. I haven't gotten it yet, but I plan on buying it sometime soon.

title: Not a great movie but worth a watch!
review: Got this movie because of the high IMDB rating.  Maybe my expectations were maybe higher than they should have been but this one was just okay.  Very good acting all around and as always Kevin Spacey was great!  I don't like stories that start out confusing until you learn enough to Â‘get it'.  Many times these movies are better the second time through so maybe I should watch it again and then rate it.  7/10

title: me-ouch
review:
kevin spacey never ceases to amaze me. this movie is no exception. excellent direction, casting, and pacing.

see it now if you haven't already, it's MORE than worth it.

i was hesitant about seeing it at first, thinking that any movie with a baldwin brother in it just *had* to be horrible, but i was pleasantly surprised.

title: Brilliant!
review: This is a movie you definitively shouldn't talk too much about before you see it, since that would ruin a lot. All I'd like to say about it is that it will wrap you up in riddles and then knock you out! This script truly is one of the best ever written on this planet. It really is. Kevin Spacey is all that can ever be asked for, but the entire cast is brilliant. Just see it and be blown away!

title: One of the best films of the Nineties!
review:
This could be one of the best films of all time...action, suspense, a wonderful cast and a superb script! It plods along slowly building toward an incredible action finale. Meanwhile if you don't pay CAREFUL attention, you WILL miss important details. So you must see it twice, or even three times to fully appreciate the trick ending.

This is a story about a group of guys with little in common except that they are thieves and know of each other by reputation. They are arrested and jailed together by accident; or is it? Are they all searching for a malevolent villain who may or may not be an enigma of time-worn imagination? Or is he manipulating them in a carefully spun web of corruption and deceit? With a whole lot of money on the line for anyone who survives. But be wary if you have small children present. There are several scenes of pretty graphic and realistic violence.

Kevin Spacey gives the performance of his remarkable career with an excellent cast of supporting players.

title: This is one of the best movies of all time!
review: This is a great movie about 5 criminals who are given a job to wak out the one guy who could possitively identify a huge man in the criminal business. The suspense is great and the end is the best ending i've ever seen in a movie, Kevin Spacey being my favorite actor and a damn good one, this makes it my favorite movie.

title: What else is there to say?
review: This movie is excellent, and quite frankly flawless.  Yes, Kevin Spacey was great in American Beauty.  However, he was absolute perfection in The Usual Suspects.  Best Supporting Actor?  Who was he supporting in this movie?  A true Spacey vehicle not afraid to tantalize and surprise.

title: Great Suspense
review: This is one of my favorite movies.  I especially liked the music, it fit the movie quite well.  I read some comments on people saying that they predicted the surprise ending not long into the movie.  Well that doesn't sound too impressive to say AFTER you have seen the whole movie.  If you didn't like the movie you just didn't like the movie, no need to stretch the truth. Surprise ending or not, it still is an excellent suspense/crime drama.

title: One of my favorites!
review: I saw this movie not expecting anything special but when I had seen it I was speechless.  At first I thought it was just a fantastic story. As I saw it again and again I realized that it very professionally made. The actors and the director do a great job in this film.  This is the kind of film you want to see again.

title: and like that... its gone...
review: and like that... its gone. This movie just soared off into the sky from the very beginning. Very, very, smart writing and a masterful direction from Synger gave this movie a spot on my top ten list. Spacey, Bryne, Baldwin... all great. Not a single problem. Also, a very shocking ending that has yet to be beaten. There's nothing like it. And just think, by watching this movie again, you could've known all along who it was. 9.5/10= *****

title: a gripping blockbuster firecracker
review:
To watch this movie once is to open a jar. A second time, it is a puzzle box. A third, a box of chocolates. You jus' never know what you gonna get.

Central to the movie, minus certain continuations, is the identity of "Keyser Soze". In the end, perhaps it is revealed and perhaps it is hoax. There is no clear answer and in that lies the value. I believe the director wanted it to be such, that we are left to ponder if the usual suspects and hence arch-criminal Keyser Soze, are perhaps figments of our mind, given life by paranoia and need to scapegoat for what lies in our own dark hearts. Who is Keyser Soze? I say, he is we, and we are him. Who is Keyser Soze if not no one and everyone at the same time? This is elucidated by multiple viewings, suggested for those interested in such fair.

title: Could be called Unusual Suspects.
review: This is one of the most unusual films that I've ever seen, and this is what makes it so appealing to me.  The ending may leave some people a bit confused, but to me, it signified an ending which hardly any other film to date has managed to achieve.  The casting is spot on, with Spacey in fine form, fully deserving the Oscar he was given for Best Supporting Actor, Baldwin is excellent with his turn as 'hard-nut' McManus a delight to behold.  This film, to me, represents a landmark in film making during the nineties, which other films of it's genre will find hard to surpass.

title: A must see for all people
review: This was probably one of the best movies ever made.  The photography was stunning, the story original (in the sense of the twist at the end, but not the plot itself), and until X-Men, Bryan Singer's best work. Kevin Spacey was great, and has become even better in his later films. Same goes for Gabriel Byrne.

title: Cheap Cinematic Ploys Ruin What Was Otherwise a Great Movie
review: I won't give away the end, but needless to say, this is a who-done-it thriller.  The movie is filled with several significant ploys designed to intentionally fool the viewer, thereby leaving the viewer with hollow feeling at the end.  For those of you who have seen "The Sixth Sense" (a tremendous movie that did not need to rely on such gimicks), you will understand what I am saying.

title: Engrossing, funny, surprising, imperfect. Caution: Spoilers!
review:
Let me begin by saying I really enjoyed this movie. Excellent plot, very good acting, good dialog, a mostly consistent tone, decent direction and music. A rare combination and hard to achieve.

Only two complaints: First, Maltin makes a good point when he says that seeing the corkboard "negates" the whole movie. After this, I would have loved to see the Customs agent imagine some possible scenarios with actors exchanging roles in the events. This could be intercut with Soeze's accurate recollections, as he speeds away, of those same events. Particularly telling would be scenes of him quietly nudging the felons toward his goals, or of slipping out to a pay phone to pass news along to "Kobayashi". (What is his name, then?) The best part would be to re-enact earlier scenes in different locations with different props and different actors in the minor roles. Oh, well. We are left to wonder whether even a quarter of what has been told is true. All you really have to hang onto at the end is the ending.

But suppose we are not so skeptical, and while taking the narration with a grain of salt, we can take the flashbacks as literal truth (albeit selective recall). I assumed that on repeated viewings I would see all the evidence to support the conclusion laid out in plain sight. No. The problem then becomes how to believe that all these events could have been orchestrated short of divine or Satanic intervention. People are hard to wrangle, especially anti-social people like our gang. Well, the more plot you fabricate the more chances for holes.

I have to say this movie does indeed work like a Swiss timepiece. Just not the kind you wear. Still, it does motor along to a big finale. Soeze pops his head out and the show's over.

Very amusing and creepy, but a little heartless, as these things usually are. Reminded me of another PolyGram persecution-and-paranoia release with a big twist.

8/10

title: Dialogue driven film noir
review: See imdb's "quotes" to give you just a hint of the quick lines and fast banter found in this movie.  The police/suspect banter is as good as the police& nazi/suspect banter in "Casablanca" (which also spawned the title) and a few saltier references.  Also the plot itself is huge: An internationally feared criminal terrorist who has an unseen web of associates murders 27 people on a freighter.  Now he emerges as a suspect to american law enforcement officers who cannot even confirm if he exists or not.  Their only witnesses are a burned survivor from the ship who claims it is the feared "Keyser Soze" and the least culpable member of the assassination squad who isn't really sure that Keyser Soze is alive or dead. Chazz Palmenteri is great as the badge-heavy/know-it-all fed as compared to the malevolent killer in Jade.  Suzi Amis is the moonstruck girlfriend that can see no evil (James Cameron left Linda Hamilton for her?!?!) and ruins her life for her felon boyfriend. The final dock scene is better than Lethal Weapon 2's final dock scene.  Keep the sound up so you can hear the patter, the reparte, as it is just so quick and glib that you'll be wishing you had some of those one-liners when the situation presents itself.  Also, incorrectly regarded as a goof is that two different planes are seen landing.  The first one (two engines) is Chazz arriving in LA to interrogate Verbal.  The second (747) is landing in NYC and holds the emerald merchant. Watch this movie and listen.  9/10

title: What can I say - brilliant!
review:
Superb. I unfortunately missed this at the cinema, but I caught it on video, as I would encourage anyone to.

There aren't many films better than this, and it'll have you guessing 'til the bitter end.

For those British films fans - imagine watching Taggart, sitting in with your girlfriend and trying to guess who the villain is - with this film you'll change your mind a dozen times, and still try to say you knew who it was at the end!

Anyone who says they saw the end is lying!!

The acting is brilliant - Gabriel Byrne is as cool as an actor (not including shaft!) can be, and Kevin Spacy gives probably his most accomplished performance - not easy when you have been the star of films such as American Beauty, The Negotiator and Se7en. He is quite simply the greatest actor of the modern era!

PLEASE watch this. You won't get much better. Who is the mysterious Kaiser Sozay?

title: kevin spacey and the story: you can't do better
review: kevin spacey is simply the best actor of our time, and this is his best role!  the film had my complete attention since the first time i watched it through the present.  the story is wonderfully detailed and the directing is well-done.  kevin spacey and the writing sum up why you want to see this movie.

title: Two Oscars, One Film, No Coincidence!
review:
Behold the ultimate film!

This is easily the best film I have ever seen and I have seen many films. The acting is superb to say the least and the script is sharp, smart and slick. I have seen this film many times, once even with the visuals turned off, just listening to the dialogue. It takes little from the film and would advise any real fan of the film to do so, simply due to the increased enjoyability of the ending.

It is the music, though, that really makes the film. John Ottman is the ultimate film music composer and it sends my whole body tingling at key times, even if I know what's happening it has the effect of the first time I saw it.

The last line(as I'm sure you have heard) is perfect, simply perfect and can make you sit dumbfounded through the whole credits.

See this film if you like tight thrillers and heck, see it if you don't!

title: This is my favourite movie of all time.
review: Let me begin by stating that this is my favourite movie of all time.  The cast is phenomenal, and Kevin Spacey in particular shines, as was clearly recognized by his winning of a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his role as Verbal Kint.  His performance is simply breathtaking, and this crime thriller is one of the most astonishing stories ever.  The plot packs all kinds of twists and turns, and the mystery remains just that until the final few minutes.  Just when you think you know everything, you find out that you don't.  Few movies can maintain a mysterious air until the end, but this one not only does that, it delivers a tremendous story along the way, brought to life by one of the best ensemble casts in the history of the movies.

title: An Instant Classic . . .
review: The smartest, slickest crime drama to come to the screen in years, maybe ever.  In the tradition of Chinatown and Double Indemnity this instant classic, follows five career criminals as they seek to pull off one simple heist as revenge against the NYPD.  But when Keyser Soze, "the devil himself" enters their plans, all they can do is try and survive.  Don't even blink, this mystery doesn't stop for moment.  The actors give the performs of their careers, capped by Kevin Spacey's Oscar winning performance as Verbal Kint and the often over looked Benicio Del Toro as Fenster.  I would put this up against any film out there.

title: Who is Keyser Soze?
review:
This is one of the best suspense movies of this past decade. Like a few others, this movie didn't rely on heavy special effects or anymore blood and guts scenes than necessary. The dialog between the characters was truly remarkable. There is not a whole lot to tell about the movie without giving anything away. What I will say about the film is that you have to pay attention to what may seem like every minor detail to actually pick up on who Keyser Soze is before the end of the film.

This is truly an original movie.

title: One of the best crime films of all time! Period!
review:
WARNING!!!!! THIS COMMENT DOES GIVE AWAY SOME OF THE MOVIE!!!!

I absolutely love this film. Bryan Singer did a wonderful job directing and Christopher McQuarrie's script is superb. He truly deserved the oscar for best original screenplay. I seriously cannot think of any flaws in this film whatsoever. The acting is brilliant, the cinematography is perfect, the editing is smooth and thfilm has one of the best endings in any film ever! WE witness a true villain. The best villain in film history in my book. Someone who murders his wife and children to save himself and use everyone around as a puppet for his own self gaining shows true evil. Kevin Spacey without a doubt played the best role in the film. I am so glad he won the Oscar. However he won for best supporting actor. To me it should have been the Best Actor award. He was basically the main character of the film. When people think of movie villains, Kevin Spacey's character Verbal Kint(Kayser Sosey) should be the first remembered.

title: An Amazing Film
review:
Surely, if you haven't seen "The Usual Suspects", you know of the great reputation it carries. Well, it deserves every bit of it. It is simply a wonderful combination of inventive film-making, a great story, and absolutely wonderful acting (and casting, for that matter).

I'm not sure I've ever seen a film where every actor in the cast was this good, especially an ensemble cast. The absolute best scenes are the dialogue that occurs between Spacey (who won a Best Supporting Actor Oscar, but has the most screentime of anyone) and Chazz Palmintieri, who is really in his element as a tough-guy cop. He never seemed to feel right in numerous bad guy roles, and he gives a great performance here as what I would term the most moral character.

There are a number of underappreciated actors who are excellent here. I've always been a big fan of Kevin Pollak, and this is by far his best dramatic role. The sam can be said of Stephen Baldwin, who luckily found time to be in this this between such forgettable films as "Bio-Dome". It was nice to see Giancarlo Esposito, who's another guy that deserves more acclaim. Dan Hedaya, who has had one of the stranger acting careers in recent memory (remember Nick Tortelli on "Cheers"?) is fine in a bit role. This is the only role I've ever like Pete Posthelwaite in, and Gabriel Byrne and Benicio Del Toro round are very good as main characters. I mention all these people because they were all that good.

The plot is original, breath-taking, and engrossing. It takes you through twists and turns you never see coming, but never takes a turn that leads to complete unbelievability (a la "The Sixth Sense"). The plot is so engrossing that the name Kaiser Soze has become part of popular lingo, despite coming from a low-budget film. The feel of the film, from the sets, to the lighting, to the actual dialogue give the perfect film noir mood.

Also - the ending is the absolute coolest (the best word I can think of) you're likely to ever see. It's and ending where you see it, and just kind of go, "Wow."

This film is easily my favorite movie, and I've seen quite a few. Nothing really matches it in the ability to have every aspect of the film of such high quality.

title: Who said it was planned?
review:
The only thing I have to say about this movie is:

Most people who are into it have had to see it at least 15000000 times.

"Do you remember the cigarette lighter dropped at the beginning, and the one at the end?"?

A hundred more.......

I at least have seen it five or six times and come out with the characters having different roles.

I love the ending that Spacy gives, about the devil.

John

title: They don't come much better than this..
review:
Well, what can you say about "The Usual Suspects"? It will go down as one of the greatest films ever made and justifiably so. Rarely can a film keep the attention of the viewer to the extent that this film does. Kevin Spacey won a deserved award for his portrayal of Verbal Kint, a crippled crook. When inadvertently teamed up with a rag-tag group of criminals including Dean Keaton (Gabriel Byrne) and Michael McManus (Stephen Baldwin). They are then set to hijack a boat for the mysterious and sadistic Keyser Soze, a legendary underworld boss.

Without wanting to give too much away, there is a wonderfully unexpected twist in the tale, better than any from any other film and it will certainly have u reaching for the rewind button.

If you haven't seen this film, go and rent it now!

title: See it...that's all I'll say.
review: I don't think there is a better suspense thriller out there.  Like others, I had to watch it twice, and I will certainly watch it again.  Never heard of it before renting it--will never forget it now that I have seen it.  There is no read-between-the-lines meaning here, just a taught, well crafted gem. Nice work, guys!

title: Just Brilliant, no flaws
review:
This would have to make my top 10 movies of all time. The movie opens with a unknown person named Kieser Soose' (pronounced Sosay) shooting a crippled Gabriel Byrne. Later on a policeman (Palminteri) is questioning cripple Verbal Kint (Oscar winner Spacey) who witnessed the murder and explosion of a boat, caused by the mysterious Soose'.

Kint tells a story about how he and 4 other crooks (Del Toro, Baldwin, Byrne and Pollack) were brought together in a police line, to do a job for the warlord Soose'. Not much more i will tell you about this unforgettable movie, with one of the best endings for a film i have seen in years. Spacey earned his Oscar for Best Supporting Actor.

10/10

title: A mind blowing action thriller that will keep you guess til the end
review: The Usual Suspects is one of the most fantastic American films ever made. I don't know a person who saw it and didn't like it. This film has everything in a good film. It contains action, great dialogue, amazing performances, thrills and a ending that will leave you speechless. For those who haven't seen it I will summarize the plot without giving too much away. Five New York criminals (Stephen Baldwin, Gabriel Byrne, Benicio Del Toro, Kevin Pollak, Kevin Spacey) team up to pull off a couple of jobs but get much more than they bargain for when they find out someone else is a step ahead of them. Along with the actors above this film features Chazz Palminteri, Pete Postlethwaite, Dan Hedaya, Suzy Amis and Peter Greene. Even though Kevin Spacey won an Oscar, all of the criminals should have gotten one. They were all in the same category and no one out shined another. This is a thriller so you will be guessing throughout  the whole thing. Plus, I can guarantee you will have no idea what is going on until about the final five minutes. The film jumps back and fourth between the past and present. Although you can tell which is which it doesn't help you figure out the story any better. This film has everything for every kind of person. This has been labeled under film-noir and crime drama it's not. This is a full blown action thriller. I put this at 5 on my all time favorite films. You you haven't experienced The Usual Suspects, please do. This is a can't miss film. And ask yourself one question, who is Keyser Soze?

title: Amazing from beginning to end.
review: In "The Usual Suspects", Keaton (Gabriel Byrne), Fenster (Benicio Del Toro), McManus (Stephen Baldwin), Hockney (Kevin Pollak), and Kint (Kevin Spacey) are arrested for a crime that one of them may have committed and put in a police line-up.  A few weeks later, there's bloody shootout in the Long Beach harbor and Kint is one of the few survivors of what happened that night.  One customs agent, Dave Kujan (Chazz Palminteri) is determined to find out what Kint didn't tell the D.A..  The conversation between Kint and Kujan is long and has a plenty of flashbacks.  The performances in this movie are played to complete perfection.  A few examples would be Spacey's that earned him a Best Supporting Oscar, Byrne and Palminteri, who should have earned at least a Best Actor nomination, and Pete Postlewaite is good as the middle man Koyabashi and maybe Keyser Soze.  John Ottman's spellbinding musical score, Newton Thomas Siegel's artistic cinematography, and Howard Cummings's colorful production design set the perfect tone.  The ending is a little bit questionable, but it's still good in a way.

title: One of the best movies of all time!!!

First off the plot in one word is magnificent. The plot unfolds through the story (to the police) of Verbal Kint (Kevin Spacey). After an explosion at the San Pedro harbour the police pick up con man, and only survivor of the explosion, Verbal Kint. Kint tells his story to the police. After a police lineup, five career criminals decide to work together. They do very well together until a mysterious crime figure decides they should work for him to repay debt owed to him. These events eventually lead to the explosion in the harbour.

The acting is magnificent most notably Kevin Spacey. The musical score and direction are both bang on.

title: Just who is Keyser SÃ¶sze?...
review: To keep it simple: definitely above average. Probably my favorite aspect of the movie, besides the really memorable characters made possible through excellent acting, is how the story is told. Kevin Spacey's character unfolds the entire film via police questioning after a series of criminal events that he and his four "friends" just recently took part in. However, the tempo seems to come to a snail's pace in some areas, but since that is about the only disappointing thing that I can find in the movie, I am willing to easily overlook it. The ending is great. I'm going to try not spoil it here, but frankly, I like it when a movie leaves it's ending up to the audience. title: You'll Never Guess the Ending
review: Acting, plot, and clever editing come together in one of the best examples of storytelling from modern times.  I never get tired of watching this movie.  The acting is top-notch by the whole cast.  The plot is completely original -- you can never guess where it'll go next.  The editing is great too, but you don't appreciate how great until the end, then you have to watch it all over again.

title: Watch this film for the acting and try to ignore the plot
review: I suppose there are two types of reactions to this film: overawed by the terrific acting and direction while disregarding the utter impossibility of the plot, or concentrating on the ridiculous plot while underestimating the fine acting.  I'd like to think that I fall somewhere in the middle.  When I saw this film in the theater I was utterly riveted by the story and the fine performances turned in the by the entire cast (I'll add my own special kudos for Pete Postlethwaite).  Walking home from the theater, however, I began to dwell on the enormous logical problems presented by the story.  Now, logical impossibility doesn't necessarily prevent a film from being great ("The Big Sleep" even confused its writers). SPOILER ALERT Ultimately, however, the ending here is not a surprise, it's a swindle.  Since the film is told, largely, from the perspective of someone who, it turns out, has been lying all the time, the viewer is left to wonder if anything happened the way it was shown.  To some, that's tantalizing ambiguity: to me, that's about as satisfying as an ending saying "and it was all a dream."  It's a lazy, desperate way for the writers to extricate themselves from a story that has outrun their powers of logical thought.  Too bad--it could have been a great movie.

title: Unusually Good
review:
I had the misfortune to miss this film when it ran in the theaters, see Kevin Spacey's Oscar acceptance speech in which he gave away the ending, and only LATER rent it on video. Despite knowing the shocker in advance, I was nonetheless mesmorized by "The Usual Suspects". In fact, it was actually kind of fun knowing the twist, because I could pay more attention to the way the twist was presented.

However, on balance, I wish I hadn't known -- my shock no doubt would have been similar to that I felt at the end of "The Sixth Sense." All in all, "The Usual Suspects" is an extremely clever piece of filmmaking, if a bit convoluted at times. Spacey is absolutely brilliant, fully deserving of his Oscar.

title: SexyFunkyCool
review:
What makes a film good? Incredible photography? Briliant Actors? Excellent plot? The Usual Suspects has all three of them. It is funk,sexy and cool at the same time. And ladies and gentlemen, that is hard to achieve. It all starts with a explosion (which was filmed at Bryan Singers backyard)where everybody dies. Only two survives. One is a burned-out bulgarian man who can only say Keyser Soze, the other is a cripple named Verbal Kint (played masterly by Kevin Spacey). It is a little difficult interviewing the bulgaraian as he is near death so it is up to Dave Kujan, a Customs interrogator to interview this cripple. What Verbal Kint gives him is a fascinating story of 5 guys trying to cooperate with Dean Keaton (Gabriel Byrne) as the leading character in the criminal group. What Kint does is to

manipulate the other suspects in the group, heist-men Michael McManus (Baldwin), Fred Fenster (Del Toro), Todd Hockney (Kevin Pollak) and Keaton. Kevin Spacey becomes soon the real hero of the film managing the difficult but not uncommon trick of really being the leading role when technically being a supporting actor. You could see this movie just for Spacey`s performance (he won an Oscar for best supporting actor). The film has some incredible Soundbites like: "The Greatest trick the Devil ever pulled was to convince the world he didn`t exist". This movie will have you on the edge of your seat. It also has what in my opinion is the best ending in movie history. And I have seen a lot of endings. This movie is altogether SexyFunkyCool. What are you waiting at? Go see it.

title: Gets Better With Age [*MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD*]
review:
The first time I saw this film was 4 years ago, when it first came out on video. I saw it because of the unbelievable praise it was given by its audience, about half of its film critics, and its two Academy Awards. After I finished the film I was both shocked and confused as to what had happened. It seemed to me everything Verbal had said to Dave Kujan was false, or some of it false, and the only confirmed truthful events or persons we actually see during the course of the film is the setup (or lineup), Verbal's testimony to the DEA, the death of the suspects except Verbal, Verbal's lies to Kujan, Kobayashi's existence, and of course the fact Keyser Soze is Verbal Kint (or could Kobayashi be Soze?)... This all took hours to figure out, but then I thought, the movie is rubbish..it just cheats at the end.

Months later The Usual Suspects was screened on TV. I gathered the will to watch it again, and I watched it with the knowledge of what happens at the end. I learned SO much more. So many little details (like the history of Keyser Soze and Dean Keaton, and their questionable past relationship or rivalry). Also, I appreciated the movie for what it is before the twist at the end: a clever, mysterious noir with great music, editing, script, characters and acting. But I still didn't fully understand the ending and its link to the flashbacks. If everything which Verbal said was shown in the flashbacks, why did Verbal admit to killing the man with the case who Keaton couldn't kill? Wouldn't that make Verbal a confessed murderer (he got set free after his testimony)? This is probably the only mysterious flaw(?) of the film.

After the second viewing, I watch the film every two or three months when I have the time. EACH time I learn something refreshingly new. This must be one of the most carefully constructed films of alltime. When you think about it the film was giving you as many clues as to who Keyser Soze really is as as many tricks to making you think Keaton is Soze: 1) the order of the gifts to the five guys from Kobayashi, and the way the camera never shows what was in Verbal's package 2) the tone of voice and the evil look Verbal gives in the lineup scene 3) the misleading, obviously tricky way the film always depicts Verbal as the last guy who could be Soze (the weasel/cripple character, the constant jokes ("gimp, pretzel man") made towards Verbal. 4) Verbal's crippled hand/leg sometimes changes from left to right throughout the film. 5) "Soz" in Turkish means word. Word and verbal a connection anyone??

If you haven't seen the film, you shouldn't be reading this.. But if you have and couldn't understand it, read my post and see it again and again!
